fields.byline: Sarah Haque, Gemma McSherry and Samantha Lock
fields.body:
7.00pm BST

Summary of today's developments

It is 9pm in Ukraine. Here are some things you mightâ€™ve missed:

  • Putin has agreed for inspectors to visit Russian-held Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in Ukraine. According to French President Emmanuel Macronâ€™s office, Putin had â€œreconsidered the demandâ€? that the International Atomic Energy Agency travel through Russia to the site, after the Russian leader himself warned fighting there could bring about a â€œcatastropheâ€?. It specified that Putin had dropped his demand that the IAEA team travel to the site via Russia, saying it could arrive via Ukraine.

  • The UN secretary-general has asked Russia not take Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant off grid. AntÃ³nio Guterres asked on Friday that the Russian-occupied Zaporizhzhia nuclear power station not be cut off from Ukraineâ€™s electrical grid after Ukrainian reports that Moscow is planning to do so, saying the plant used â€œUkrainian electricityâ€?.

  • Western officials say that there are growing concerns over concerns over water cooling at Russian-held nuclear power plant. The existing reactor cooling system at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant is critical to the safety of the site and relies on the maintenance of the electricity supply to ensure operation â€“ but officials are anxious that Russia may disconnect the supply if it tries to cut off the plant from the Ukrainian grid.

  • More than half of Russia Black Sea naval aviation has been knocked out, according to a western official in Ukraine. results.webTitle: Did Vietnam peace protests stop Nixon using nuclear weapons?

fields.headline: Did Vietnam peace protests stop Nixon using nuclear weapons?
fields.standfirst: A new documentary, released amid Putinâ€™s brinksmanship over Ukraine, argues that marches in 1969 changed the US presidentâ€™s mind. Some historians think otherwise
fields.trailText: A new documentary, released amid Putinâ€™s brinksmanship over Ukraine, argues that marches in 1969 changed the US presidentâ€™s mind. Some historians think otherwise
fields.body:
A new documentary about demonstrations against the Vietnam war in late 1969 argues that the hundreds of thousands who filled the streets in Washington and almost every major US city convinced Richard Nixon to abandon a plan to sharply escalate the war, including the possible use of tactical nuclear weapons.

Related: â€˜We may have lost the southâ€™: what LBJ really said about Democrats in 1964

The Movement and The â€œMadmanâ€? will air on PBS on Tuesday. Produced and directed by the veteran documentarian Stephen Talbot, it evokes a peak moment of 1960s activism â€“ and the â€œabsolute disconnectionâ€? between what Nixon and his national security adviser, Henry Kissinger, were â€œdeciding to do and the human costs of it, whether itâ€™s to our own soldiers or [Vietnamese] civiliansâ€?.

Those costs â€œhad absolutely no part of their thinkingâ€? said the historian Carolyn Eisenberg. â€œThey donâ€™t care.â€?

Talbotâ€™s sure eye for searing images is matched by a perfect ear for songs. His soundtrack includes anti-establishment hymns by Bob Dylan, Pete Seeger, Jimi Hendrix and Judy Collins, plus the essential anti-war anthem, I-Feel-Like-Iâ€™m Fixinâ€™-to-Die Rag, which became world famous after Country Joe McDonald performed it at Woodstock in summer 1969.

The one thing the documentary does not do is provide any convincing evidence that the demonstrations prevented the use of nuclear weapons.

â€œIt is a serious look at how one major demonstration was organized,â€? said Thomas Powers, author of The War at Home, a history of the anti-war movement; The Man Who Kept the Secrets, a widely admired biography of the former CIA director Richard Helms; and seven other books.

But as far as the idea that â€œa real danger of the use of atomic weapons was prevented [by the Vietnam Moratorium] â€“ I think thatâ€™s just plain wrongâ€?, Powers told the Guardian.

Talbot responded that declassified documents about Operation Duck Hook, which laid out options for Nixon, included the possible use of nuclear weapons as well as the mining of Haiphong harbor and the bombing of dykes that would have caused massive civilian casualties.

As to whether Nixon seriously considered the nuclear option, Talbot said: â€œI literally donâ€™t know and I donâ€™t think anyone could say for sure. But it was on the table.â€?

The â€œmadmanâ€? of Talbotâ€™s film is Nixon. One thing that is not in dispute is that the president worked hard to convince the North Vietnamese and the Russians he was crazy enough to do anything, including pulling the nuclear trigger, if Hanoi refused his demands to withdraw from the south.

As Stephen Bull, a former Nixon aide, explains in the film, his boss wanted the Russians to â€œthink that he was a madman. However, my personal observation was, it was a bluff. He was never going to use nuclear weapons, but he wanted the threat to be out there to force them to the table.â€?

Powers likened Nixonâ€™s threats to use nuclear bombs to Vladimir Putinâ€™s current threats to use such weapons against Ukraine â€“ which Powers doesnâ€™t think are serious either. Talbot agreed that was a possibility.

In his memoirs, Nixon wrote: â€œAlthough publicly I continued to ignore the raging anti-war controversy, I had to face the fact that it had probably destroyed the credibility of my ultimatum to Hanoi.â€?

The other thing the demonstrations almost certainly accomplished was the passage of a law, signed by Nixon in November 1969, which created a draft lottery.

On 1 December 1969, every draft-eligible young man born between 1944 and 1950 was assigned a number based on his birth date, from one to 365. The following year, the Pentagon announced that no one with a number higher than 195 would be drafted. A year later that number dropped to 125, then to 95 the year after that.

Since everyone in the streets in 1969 was demonstrating in no small part because of an acute desire to avoid dying in what they considered a pointless conflict, the lottery had an immediate effect in reducing the number who felt a sense of urgency about the war.

If you had a high enough number, your life was no longer in danger. After the very first lottery, more than a third of those previously subject to the draft no longer felt any imminent jeopardy. So there was less self-interest to propel the anti-war protests.

Talbot agreed that the lottery was a direct result of the anti-war demonstrations, and said he included it in an earlier, longer version of his film â€“ but it did not make the final cut. In fall 1969, he was a senior in college. He went to DC to make his first film, March on Washington, which became his senior thesis when he attended Wesleyan University.

Related: Victor Navasky, the New York Times and a key moment in gay history

â€œI used clips from my first student film for this documentary,â€? he told the Guardian.

The truth is, while the Vietnam demonstrations did reduce the dangers of the draft, there is almost no evidence they shortened the war. When Nixon took office, 31,000 Americans had been killed in Vietnam, plus hundreds of thousands of Vietnamese. By the time the last American combat troops left in March 1973, two months after the draft was abolished, 58,220 US soldiers had died â€“ plus as many as 2 million Vietnamese civilians and 1.3 million Vietnamese soldiers.

  • The Movement and The â€˜Madmanâ€™ airs on PBS at 9pm ET on Tuesday and will stream on pbs.org

  • Charles Kaiserâ€™s books include 1968: Music, Politics, Chaos, Counterculture, and the Shaping of a Generation

fields.headline: UK arm of EDF returns to profit as household electricity prices soar
fields.standfirst: French firmâ€™s 2022 pre-tax figure of Â£1.1bn in Britain relates to nuclear operations and higher energy prices
fields.trailText: French firmâ€™s 2022 pre-tax figure of Â£1.1bn in Britain relates to nuclear operations and higher energy prices
fields.body:
The UK arm of the French energy company EDF bounced back to profit last year, making more than Â£1bn, as it was boosted by the rising cost of wholesale energy, which allowed it to sell the electricity it generated at a higher price.

The firm made a pre-tax profit of Â£1.1bn in the UK last year, before one-off items, a recovery from a loss of Â£21m a year earlier.

EDF, which runs Britainâ€™s nuclear power stations, said the profit was related to stronger operational performance of its nuclear fleet, and higher energy prices.

Related: Centrica boss refuses to say if he will waive bonus after â€˜obsceneâ€™ Â£3.3bn profit

The company is building Britainâ€™s newest nuclear reactor, Hinkley Point C in Somerset, which has been hit by delays and climbing costs. The cost of the project was originally set at Â£18bn, before it was later put at Â£25bn to Â£26bn.

On Friday, EDF said that Â£25bn to Â£26bn remained the estimated cost based on 2015 calculations but â€œthe estimated nominal cost at completion could reach Â£32.7bnâ€? because of inflation.

The company, which is mostly state-owned but is being fully nationalised in France, is the UKâ€™s fourth-largest energy supplier, providing gas and electricity to more than 5m UK households.

EDF said Britainâ€™s cap on energy bills hit earnings at its energy supply business, which made a loss of Â£200m. The company said this was because it cost it more to buy energy to supply to its residential customers than the price it was allowed to charge them under the energy price cap.

The UK profit was a rare bright spot for EDF in its annual results, which reported a record net loss of â‚¬17.9bn (Â£16bn) for the whole group in 2022, as its nuclear output plunged to a 34-year low after a record number of outages at its reactors in France. Stress corrosion cracks were found in pipes in the cooling systems of some reactors.

The groupâ€™s net debt rose to almost â‚¬65bn last year, up from â‚¬43bn a year earlier.

EDFâ€™s chief executive, Luc RÃ©mont, who was appointed by the French government last November to turn the company around, said: â€œToday, our priority is to put EDF back on track.â€?

EDF said it invested Â£2.6bn in the UK in 2022 in its nuclear, renewables and customer businesses.

The company said it was investing more than Â£13bn in the UK between 2023 and 2025, largely in the Hinkley Point scheme.

It is also planning to invest about Â£2bn in its existing nuclear fleet and renewables projects this year.

It welcomed the UK governmentâ€™s decision last November confirming that the Sizewell C nuclear power plant in Suffolk would go ahead, and which will be developed by EDF.

The government has taken a 50% stake in the project, which will be the second of a new generation of UK nuclear power reactors, after Hinkley Point C.

results.webTitle: We need more honesty on nuclear powerâ€™s long legacy of hazardous waste | Letters

fields.headline: We need more honesty on nuclear powerâ€™s long legacy of hazardous waste
fields.standfirst: Tom Smith, William Walker and Neil Smith respond to Samanth Subramanianâ€™s long read on the enormous task of dismantling Sellafield
fields.trailText: Letters: Tom Smith, William Walker and Neil Smith respond to Samanth Subramanianâ€™s long read on the enormous task of dismantling Sellafield
fields.body:
Samanth Subramanian captures perfectly the vast scale and longevity of the effort needed to clean up Sellafield (The long read, 15 December). As Britain and other states with nuclear power industries grapple with how to go about an effective, safe and economical nuclear clean-up, it might be better to explain the challenges with less reliance on suggestions that in its early days the nuclear industry never thought about decommissioning (though the point has validity). Instead, we need more honesty about the fact that nuclear power inescapably generates large quantities of hazardous human-made waste, the worst of which will remain hazardous probably beyond Homo sapiensâ€™ time on the planet.

The industryâ€™s solution to this is a network of deep disposal facilities. But none have yet been created, their cost is enormous and there is no certainty that they will perform the long-term task required of them. These are considerations that sadly receive little attention in current debates about the need for new nuclear-generation capacity.

Coincidentally, you published a letter (14 December) suggesting that nuclear radiation is less dangerous than emissions from a wood-burning stove, a curious comparison to make. Wood-burning stoves are pollutants, no question, but they could never lead to a Windscale, Three Mile Island, Chornobyl or Fukushima. Nor will decommissioning them cost billions and take decades.
Tom Smith
Chair, Nuclear Decommissioning Authority, 2017-20

â€¢ In 1993, a government official told me that â€œit was sometimes right to do the wrong thingâ€?. For reasons of political expediency, it was right to give political consent for the operation of the thermal oxide reprocessing plant (Thorp) at Sellafield. This huge facility, not mentioned in Samanth Subramanianâ€™s fine long read, had been built over the previous decade to reprocess British and foreign, especially Japanese, spent nuclear fuels. Abandoning it would be too embarrassing for the many politicians and their parties that had backed it, expensive in terms of compensation for broken contracts, and damaging to Britainâ€™s and the nuclear industryâ€™s international reputation.

It was wrong to proceed, as the government well knew, because the primary justification for its construction â€“ supply of plutonium for fast breeder reactors (FBRs) â€“ had been swept away by the abandonment of FBRs in the 1980s (none were built anywhere). Because returning Thorpâ€™s separated plutonium and radwaste to Japan would be difficult and risky. Because decommissioning Thorp would become much more costly after its radioactive contamination. Because there was a known win-win solution, favoured by most utilities â€“ store the spent fuel safely at Sellafield prior to its return to senders, avoiding the many troubles that lay ahead.

Thorp operated fitfully until its closure in 2018. The 30 tonnes of plutonium that it separated remains at Sellafield â€“ another waste to trouble generations to come.
William Walker

As Britain and other states with nuclear power industries grapple with how to go about an effective, safe and economical nuclear clean-up, it might be better to explain the challenges with less reliance on suggestions that in its early days the nuclear industry never thought about decommissioning (though the point has validity). Instead, we need more honesty about the fact that nuclear power inescapably generates large quantities of hazardous human-made waste, the worst of which will remain hazardous probably beyond Homo sapiensâ€™ time on the planet. The industryâ€™s solution to this is a network of deep disposal facilities. But none have yet been created, their cost is enormous and there is no certainty that they will perform the long-term task required of them. These are considerations that sadly receive little attention in current debates about the need for new nuclear-generation capacity. Coincidentally, you published a letter (14 December) suggesting that nuclear radiation is less dangerous than emissions from a wood-burning stove, a curious comparison to make. Wood-burning stoves are pollutants, no question, but they could never lead to a Windscale, Three Mile Island, Chornobyl or Fukushima. Nor will decommissioning them cost billions and take decades. fields.standfirst: Artificial lawns are more popular than ever â€“ but they are also an environmental nightmare. Will the campaign to stop them be successful?
fields.trailText: Artificial lawns are more popular than ever â€“ but they are also an environmental nightmare. Will the campaign to stop them be successful?
fields.body:
My lawn is a disaster. To be honest, itâ€™s not really a lawn at all. Any green is mostly moss, the rest is mud. More no manâ€™s land than bowling green. The reasons for this are: small London garden (I know I am lucky to have one); not a lot of sun (stolen by the neighbourâ€™s overhanging apple tree); two footballing boys (even though, now banned for life, they have to go to the park). And possibly also inexpertise on the part of the groundsman, though he has tried â€“ Iâ€™ve turfed, and seeded, aerated, watered, fed, scarified, sung to it. Iâ€™m about ready to give up.

There is an obvious solution: artificial grass. Beautifully, uniformly verdant all year round, low maintenance, no mowing required, no mower required, no watering, no mud. I might even let the boys back on to it. Or not.

Iâ€™m not alone in thinking of faking it. A survey last year by Aviva found that 10% of UK homeowners with outside space had replaced at least some of their gardenâ€™s natural lawn with artificial grass, and a further 29% plan to or would consider making the swap. During the pandemic, when everyone was thinking about the outdoors, searches for â€œartificial grassâ€? jumped 185% from May 2019 to 2020, according to Google Trends.

My own search finds dozens of firms offering artificial grass, seducing me with pictures of lawns that look like the green baize of snooker tables. And promises â€“ no mud, no sweat, no tears. And no guilt either â€“ hereâ€™s one that says itâ€™s â€œbetter for the environmentâ€? â€“ because you donâ€™t have to water, mow or fertilise. Well, thatâ€™s a relief, though weâ€™ll return to this later.

I might miss the smell of summer: freshly cut grass. What, I donâ€™t have to? I can brush in artificial grass cleaner with that very fragrance? Happy days. Soon I have a quote for supply and installation, 40 sq metres of a mid-range product: Â£2,900 plus VAT. Ouch. But you can just buy the stuff for as little as Â£7 a sq metre â€“ how hard can it be to DIY?

Artificial grass was invented by James M Faria and Robert T Wright at Monsanto and first installed on a recreation area of a school in Providence Rhode Island in 1964. It hit the headlines a couple of years later when it was laid in the Astrodome in Houston, Texas, and became known as AstroTurf.

Artificial turf for sport, now produced under different brand names by other companies, has become increasingly controversial, most seriously after being potentially linked to the deaths of six professional baseball players in Philadelphia, who had the same rare form of cancer. It often uses rubber granules from recycled tyres, which can contain heavy metals, benzene and other carcinogens. Artificial grass for domestic use and landscaping, which began to be a thing in the 1990s, is normally made from polypropylene or nylon (polyamide) and doesnâ€™t often contain rubber granules. The global artificial turf market (including sports use and domestic use) grew 8.4% in the past year to $4.87 bn (Â£3.95bn) and is expected to reach $6.83 bn (Â£5.6bn) in 2027. No wonder so many companies want to put plastic over your garden.

Before I take the plunge, I ask Guardian readers to share their experiences of artificial lawns. Some are positive. Several, including Don in Fife and Wayne in Worcester, mention their dogs digging up the old grass. And Alex in Surreyâ€™s greyhounds used to bring mud into the house. Not any more. As well as dogs, children come up. â€œItâ€™s been wonderful, and the grandchildren love it,â€? says Charles in Berkshire. And when it comes to croquet, in-house knowledge of the small bumps and inconsistencies in the surface allows them â€œto win against all comersâ€?. Home advantage â€“ I like it.

It was brilliant to have a party on, people put their fags out on it and it was fine

Phil in Weston-super-Mare did it for his son to play football on â€“ just a little bit in the goalmouth, â€œso it didnâ€™t become a mud bathâ€?. It was the same for Genevieve in Kent: her kids turned the garden into a quagmire, so they put down fake grass. â€œIt was the most successful thing â€“ they just played football all the time. It was brilliant to have a party on too â€“ people put their fags out on it and it was fine. I think it would survive nuclear Armageddon.â€?

This was a while back, in the 00s, when her family were pioneers of artificial grass. Theyâ€™ve moved house since then: â€œWe wouldnâ€™t get artificial grass now.â€? Not just because the kids have grown up. â€œBecause of all the reasons we now know we shouldnâ€™t have it.â€?

***

â€˜I canâ€™t stand plastic grass!â€? bellows the naturalist Iolo Williams, who presents the BBCâ€™s Springwatch, speaking from his home in mid-Wales. â€œIt is hugely damaging to the environment on several levels. First of all it takes away the natural habitat from a whole host of species, notably invertebrates like earthworms, valuable in their own right but also a valuable food source for all kinds of birds and mammals.â€?

Last yearâ€™s WWF Living Planet Report found that globally, wildlife populations have plunged by 69% over the past 50 years, with the UK one of the most nature-depleted countries in Europe. This is not the time to be destroying natural habitats and breaking up food chains.

â€œIf you want to see blackbirds and song thrushes, youâ€™ve got to have grass full of invertebrates,â€? says Williams. â€œPeople are lamenting the decline of a lot of these birds, but if you stick down plastic grass, what do you expect? You reap what you sow. I would love to see plastic grass banned once and for all. It makes me very angry. I absolutely detest it.â€?

Lynne Marcus, co-chair of the Society of Garden Designers, also underlines the fact that artificial lawns are no-go zones for wildlife. â€œPeople may say butterflies or bees can land around it, on the strips of soil we have with a few plants, but itâ€™s like if you put a motorway down the middle of a forest. The animals canâ€™t get from one side to the other to procreate.â€?

With support from the Royal Horticultural Society and the Landscape Institute, the society has launched a campaign on this issue. It wants people to say no to fake grass. The charge sheet is a long one: artificial lawns destroy natural habitats and soil; they contribute to carbon emissions during manufacture and transport, whereas real grass absorbs CO2; they overheat in the summer and contribute to urban heat islands; they cause flooding as they absorb less than 50% of the rain that falls on them; they pollute waterways, as over time the plastic breaks down into microplastics, which is washed into our drainage and discharged into rivers and the sea; they are neither biodegradable nor recyclable, and after their life cycle (typically up to about 15 years) they go into landfill where they will continue to pollute.

In short, they are an environmental nightmare, green in colour only. â€œEvery time you put one down, youâ€™re saying: â€˜I know weâ€™re all worried about climate change, but guess what, Iâ€™m going to contribute to it,â€™â€? says Marcus, before adding that she doesnâ€™t want to blame people. â€œItâ€™s about public engagement with the issue, informing and educating.â€?

She rejects any idea that they are maintenance-free, explaining that over time they accumulate a buildup of excrement and urine from birds, mice, foxes, cats and dogs, and have to be regularly cleaned and disinfected.

You canâ€™t get a plastic bag, yet you can cover your garden in plastic. It seems to me there should be something illegal about that

â€œYou canâ€™t get a plastic bag, yet you can cover your garden in plastic,â€? says Marcus. â€œIt seems to me there should be something illegal about that.â€? And she thinks that in years to come weâ€™ll look back at it in the same way as we now look back at driving without seatbelts or smoking next to babies. â€œOh my God, can you believe it, we used to lay plastic lawns!â€?

The tide does seem to be turning. The Chelsea Flower show banned fake grass last year. Ed Horne of the RHS, which runs the event, said: â€œFake grass is just not in line with our ethos and views on plastic. We recommend using real grass because of its environmental benefits, which include supporting wildlife, mitigating flooding and cooling the environment.â€? The housing secretary Michael Gove plans to prevent developers from laying fake grass in new housing schemes.

The mood is reflected in some more of our reader responses. In Somerset, JP put down a plastic lawn because it was a tiny patch and grass wouldnâ€™t grow. â€œWithin months it started stinking of urine due to the dog toileting on it. About six months ago weâ€™d had enough and I ripped it out. I regret the waste of plastic. We now have a sedum lawn, which loves poor soil and is fantastic for pollinators. I wish weâ€™d done that all along.â€?

In South Ayrshire, Dennis inherited a plastic lawn when they moved to their place. â€œIt was filthy, and had faded to a light insipid green.â€? So they removed it, and the gravel underneath, imported topsoil and compost, and planted butterfly- and bee-friendly shrubs and flowers. â€œOur garden, lifeless before, is now full of life.â€?

Barbara Samitier, a French garden designer working in London, thinks that the need for a perfect green lawn may be a peculiarly British thing. â€œYou canâ€™t imagine a garden without it. I think it belongs to the kind of imagery maybe from cricket, Wimbledon, this green and pleasant land. Itâ€™s what people in this country have been raised to see as nature.â€?

There are alternatives that arenâ€™t plastic, even if you have a small, north-facing city garden and children. â€œYou can do a little woodland, make it more a sort of exploratory playground. A family garden doesnâ€™t need to be about an expanse of lawn â€“ there are different ways to engage children outdoors.â€?

Even if you have a lawn, it doesnâ€™t have to look like Centre Court on the opening day of Wimbledon. â€œIf I look at a perfect lawn, it doesnâ€™t make me feel relaxed,â€? says Samitier. â€œIâ€™m thinking it uses a lot of water, requires a lot of cutting, also chemicals to keep it weed-free and to keep it going in spite of the changes in weather. Whereas if I look at a less perfect lawn with maybe some long grass, areas that havenâ€™t been mown, I know there is a lot of life in there, insects and pollinators. For me, that looks a lot more beautiful.â€?

Itâ€™s about accepting the seasons. â€œIt doesnâ€™t have to be perfect all the time, so in the winter it gets muddy, in the summer itâ€™s dry but thatâ€™s fine: it comes back when it rains. I think in England a lot of gardens are about ego and controlling, making everything do exactly what you want, the grass needs to be perfect and all of this. But now we see the beauty of letting go a bit and accepting we donâ€™t have to control everything.â€?

Artificial grass makes Samitierâ€™s heart sink. â€œDonâ€™t do it! Youâ€™ll regret it,â€? she warns me.

But itâ€™s OK, because Iâ€™m already moving away from plasticking over my scruffy little urban patch and trying to see it in a new light. Not mud and mess, but life and beauty â€¦ well, letâ€™s not carried away. Not no manâ€™s land, though, nor no beastâ€™s land. There is birdsong. And right on cue, almost as if it was paid, a dunnock shuffles on to my not-lawn and starts hopping around, hunting for breakfast.

You reap what you sow. I would love to see plastic grass banned once and for all. It makes me very angry. I absolutely detest it.â€? Lynne Marcus, co-chair of the Society of Garden Designers, also underlines the fact that artificial lawns are no-go zones for wildlife. â€œPeople may say butterflies or bees can land around it, on the strips of soil we have with a few plants, but itâ€™s like if you put a motorway down the middle of a forest. The animals canâ€™t get from one side to the other to procreate.â€? With support from the Royal Horticultural Society and the Landscape Institute, the society has launched a campaign on this issue. It wants people to say no to fake grass. The charge sheet is a long one: artificial lawns destroy natural habitats and soil; they contribute to carbon emissions during manufacture and transport, whereas real grass absorbs CO2; they overheat in the summer and contribute to urban heat islands; they cause flooding as they absorb less than 50% of the rain that falls on them; they pollute waterways, as over time the plastic breaks down into microplastics, which is washed into our drainage and discharged into rivers and the sea; they are neither biodegradable nor recyclable, and after their life cycle (typically up to about 15 years) they go into landfill where they will continue to pollute. In short, they are an environmental nightmare, green in colour only. â€œEvery time you put one down, youâ€™re saying: â€˜I know weâ€™re all worried about climate change, but guess what, Iâ€™m going to contribute to it,â€™â€? says Marcus, before adding that she doesnâ€™t want to blame people. â€œItâ€™s about public engagement with the issue, informing and educating.â€? She rejects any idea that they are maintenance-free, explaining that over time they accumulate a buildup of excrement and urine from birds, mice, foxes, cats and dogs, and have to be regularly cleaned and disinfected. â€œYou canâ€™t get a plastic bag, yet you can cover your garden in plastic,â€? says Marcus. â€œIt seems to me there should be something illegal about that.â€? And she thinks that in years to come weâ€™ll look back at it in the same way as we now look back at driving without seatbelts or smoking next to babies. â€œOh my God, can you believe it, we used to lay plastic lawns!â€? The tide does seem to be turning. The Chelsea Flower show banned fake grass last year. Ed Horne of the RHS, which runs the event, said: â€œFake grass is just not in line with our ethos and views on plastic. We recommend using real grass because of its environmental benefits, which include supporting wildlife, mitigating flooding and cooling the environment.â€? The housing secretary Michael Gove plans to prevent developers from laying fake grass in new housing schemes. The mood is reflected in some more of our reader responses. In Somerset, JP put down a plastic lawn because it was a tiny patch and grass wouldnâ€™t grow. â€œWithin months it started stinking of urine due to the dog toileting on it. About six months ago weâ€™d had enough and I ripped it out. I regret the waste of plastic. We now have a sedum lawn, which loves poor soil and is fantastic for pollinators. I wish weâ€™d done that all along.â€? In South Ayrshire, Dennis inherited a plastic lawn when they moved to their place. â€œIt was filthy, and had faded to a light insipid green.â€? So they removed it, and the gravel underneath, imported topsoil and compost, and planted butterfly- and bee-friendly shrubs and flowers. â€œOur garden, lifeless before, is now full of life.â€? Barbara Samitier, a French garden designer working in London, thinks that the need for a perfect green lawn may be a peculiarly British thing. â€œYou canâ€™t imagine a garden without it. I think it belongs to the kind of imagery maybe from cricket, Wimbledon, this green and pleasant land. Itâ€™s what people in this country have been raised to see as nature.â€? There are alternatives that arenâ€™t plastic, even if you have a small, north-facing city garden and children. â€œYou can do a little woodland, make it more a sort of exploratory playground. A family garden doesnâ€™t need to be about an expanse of lawn â€“ there are different ways to engage children outdoors.â€? Even if you have a lawn, it doesnâ€™t have to look like Centre Court on the opening day of Wimbledon. â€œIf I look at a perfect lawn, it doesnâ€™t make me feel relaxed,â€? says Samitier. â€œIâ€™m thinking it uses a lot of water, requires a lot of cutting, also chemicals to keep it weed-free and to keep it going in spite of the changes in weather. Whereas if I look at a less perfect lawn with maybe some long grass, areas that havenâ€™t been mown, I know there is a lot of life in there, insects and pollinators. For me, that looks a lot more beautiful.â€? Itâ€™s about accepting the seasons. â€œIt doesnâ€™t have to be perfect all the time, so in the winter it gets muddy, in the summer itâ€™s dry but thatâ€™s fine: it comes back when it rains. I think in England a lot of gardens are about ego and controlling, making everything do exactly what you want, the grass needs to be perfect and all of this. But now we see the beauty of letting go a bit and accepting we donâ€™t have to control everything.â€? Artificial grass makes Samitierâ€™s heart sink. â€œDonâ€™t do it! Youâ€™ll regret it,â€? she warns me. But itâ€™s OK, because Iâ€™m already moving away from plasticking over my scruffy little urban patch and trying to see it in a new light. fields.headline: Albanese government approves first new coalmine since taking power
fields.standfirst:
Environment activists condemn expected decision by Tanya Plibersek to give green light to Isaac River project in central Queensland

  • Follow our Australia news live blog for the latest updates
  • Get our morning and afternoon news emails, free app or daily news podcast
fields.trailText: Environment activists condemn expected decision by Tanya Plibersek to give green light to Isaac River project in central Queensland
fields.body:
The Australian government has approved a new coalmine development for the first time since it was elected last year.

Tanya Plibersek, the federal environment minister, indicated she would give the green light to the Isaac River coalmine in Queenslandâ€™s Bowen basin. It was announced late on Thursday.

The mine, to be developed by Bowen Coking Coal, is planned for 28km east of Moranbah, next to five other coalmines, and expected to produce about 500,000 tonnes of metallurgical coal a year for five years. Metallurgical coal, also known as coking coal, is used in steelmaking.

Related: Dozens of climate activists arrested after shovelling coal from train bound for Newcastle

â€œThe Albanese government has to make decisions in accordance with the facts and the national environment law â€“ thatâ€™s what happens on every project, and thatâ€™s whatâ€™s happened here,â€? a spokesperson for Plibersek said.

â€œSince the election weâ€™ve doubled renewable energy approvals to a record high. The government will continue to consider each project on a case-by-case basis, under the law.â€?

The government said no submissions had been received about the project during the public consultation period, including from environment groups.

But climate campaigners had made public statements calling on Plibersek to reject the mine in line with scientific advice that no new fossil fuel developments should go ahead if the world is to limit global heating to 1.5C.

â€œScientists, energy and climate experts have said that the climate cannot afford new coalmines, and theyâ€™ve said it so many times Iâ€™ve lost count,â€? said Rod Campbell, research director at the Australia Institute.

â€œThe fact that this is a small coking coalmine is beside the point â€“ fossil carbon needs to stay in the ground. Weâ€™ve already got more than enough coalmines approved to cook the planet, including coking coalmines that could run into next century.

â€œThis approval comes late in the evening in budget week, the perfect time for controversial news.â€?

The announcement comes a week after Plibersek cancelled two coal projects whose applications had lapsed.

Dr Coral Rowston, the director of EnvA (Environmental Advocacy) CQ, a grassroots group in central Queensland, said the project would affect habitat for the vulnerable ornamental snake.

â€œThe other key issue for us is the mine will also leave a legacy for our water quality in central Queensland due to the release of affected water from sediment dams into the Isaac River which feeds into the Great Barrier Reef.â€?

Plibersek also plans to move three other projects â€“ two in New South Wales and one in Queensland â€“ to the next stage of the assessment process.

The three mines are among a group of 19 proposed new coal and gas projects that Environment Justice Australia, on behalf of the Environment Council of Central Queensland, had sought to have reconsidered and effectively rejected because of their potential greenhouse gas emissions.

â€œTodayâ€™s decision means minister Plibersek joins a long line of federal environment ministers who have said itâ€™s not their job to consider the climate risk of new coal and gas mines,â€? the councilâ€™s president Christine Carlisle said.

The government found it could not stop the projects at this point in the process because national environmental laws state they would have to prove the emissions of a specific project would be a substantial cause of climate change effects on matters of national environmental significance.

Of the remaining 16 projects, five have been withdrawn by the developers or cancelled by the government due to lapsed applications. Thursdayâ€™s decision leaves 11 still to be reconsidered by Plibersek.

Environmental Justice Australia senior lawyer Retta Berryman said: â€œOur client is carefully considering all legal options in light of todayâ€™s decision â€“ including one or more federal court challenges.â€?

â€¢ This article was amended on 12 May 2023 to remove a statement from Coral Rowston referring to koala and greater glider habitat. The Isaac River mine that has been approved would not affect those areas.

results.webTitle: China ramps up coal power despite carbon neutral pledges

fields.headline: China ramps up coal power despite carbon neutral pledges
fields.standfirst: Local governments approved more coal power in first three months of 2023 than all of 2021
fields.trailText: Local governments approved more coal power in first three months of 2023 than all of 2021
fields.body:
Local governments in China approved more new coal power in the first three months of 2023 than in the whole of 2021, according to official documents.

The approvals, analysed by Greenpeace, reveal that between January and March this year, at least 20.45 gigawatts of coal power was approved, up from 8.63GW in the same period in 2022. In the whole of 2021, 18GW of coal was approved.

A Chinese Communist party (CCP) five-year plan from 2016 had placed a heavy emphasis on reducing the use of coal and developing clean energy sources. In 2020 Xi Jinping, Chinaâ€™s leader, pledged that the country would become carbon neutral by 2060.

This prompted an era of reduced coal power approvals as local governments sought to keep their local economies in check with Beijingâ€™s priorities. A rise in coal power approvals came in 2020 when the five-year plan came to an end, as local governments anticipated even tighter restrictions on coal expansion in the next round.

But in 2021, China suffered huge power outages, leading to a dramatic shift in the CCPâ€™s energy priorities. In September the price of electricity soared as factories reopened to service global demand as the rest of the world emerged from the Covid-19 pandemic. But the government had capped prices, so many power plants reduced output rather than operated at a loss.

China relies on coal for more than half of its energy consumption. As homes in the colder north of the country faced the prospect of a gruelling winter without heat, the governmentâ€™s rhetoric shifted from reducing coal to prioritising energy security. That resulted in a â€œmyth that if you build more power plants, that will bring more energy security,â€? said Xie Wenwen, a climate and energy campaigner at Greenpeace.

The war in Ukraine, which sent global energy prices soaring, was â€œanother huge event that fuelled the energy security narrativeâ€?.

Campaigners argue that in order to meet Chinaâ€™s growing energy needs, it is not more coal that is needed, but a more flexible grid. A report published this month by the Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air, noted that technologies for storing clean energy â€œare not yet mature enough to be deployed at the scale considered essentialâ€? for Chinaâ€™s plans to expand the use of renewable energy.

More than 75% of Chinaâ€™s coal, wind, solar and hydro resources are in the west of the country, while more than 70% of power consumption happens in central and eastern China. Five provinces on the east coast account for nearly two-fifths of Chinaâ€™s total consumption. Policymakers have yet to find a solution for efficiently rebalancing this problem.

Still, in the 14th five-year plan, which covers the period until 2025, the government said that more than half of increased energy demands in that period should be covered by renewables. Between 2010 and 2021, renewable generation increased by an average annual rate of 19.2%, primarily from wind and solar power.

But last year Xi said that coal would remain a mainstay of Chinaâ€™s energy mix that â€œwould be hard to change in the short termâ€?.

results.webTitle: Protest review â€“ schoolgirls unite with the power of dissent

fields.headline: Protest review â€“ schoolgirls unite with the power of dissent
fields.standfirst:
Northern Stage, Newcastle
This show for young audiences builds to a stirring drama of waking up to injustice and trying to right it
fields.trailText: This show for young audiences builds to a stirring drama of waking up to injustice and trying to right it
fields.body:
Hannah Lavery constructs her play from simple sentences. Her language is clear and direct. Each line builds on the last, with primary-school economy. At first, the picture she paints is unremarkable. It is all relay races, bird watching and maths classes. We hear about grandmas, fathers and big brothers. It is as familiar as the monkey bars on Amy Jane Cookâ€™s pastel-coloured set with its pleasing geometric shapes.

In interlinking monologues, we meet Alice (Kirsty MacLaren), determined to triumph in the school sports day; Jade (Tamara Fairbairn), certain her family history can enrich the curriculum; and Chloe (EsmÃ© Kingdom), wishing she could connect with people as well as she can the environment. Excellently played, they are eager to please, prone to extravagant bursts of energy and, beneath it all, vexed about a world that is not quite right.

Backed by Northern Stage, Fuel, Imaginate and the National Theatre of Scotland, Natalie Ibuâ€™s energetic production has the innocuous air of the playground. Aimed at 8â€“13 year olds, it initially seems to be more about the excitement of learning than the trauma of high-stakes drama.

Yet the more Lavery draws us in, the more the picture of innocent youth fractures. Could that be racist graffiti newly painted on Jadeâ€™s way to school? Did someone really dump a mattress in Chloeâ€™s treasured woods? And how is it the boys always get chosen for the team when everyone knows Alice is the fastest?

Like the â€œbrittle welcomeâ€? that met Jadeâ€™s great grandmother and her â€œfriends from the empireâ€? during the war, the security of these girls is provisional. But, asks Lavery, what if they resisted? What if, with their chalk marks, posters and passions, they made a stand for feminism, inclusivity and the climate? What if their small changes could become big changes?

As she asks those questions, and as the answers come into focus, so the structure of Protest shifts. No longer is this a play about solo turns, lone voices searching for confirmation. Now it is about collective action and the power of a united front. The girls come together and, in a breathtaking moment, the whole audience rises to assert its communal will.

  • At Northern Stage, Newcastle, until 6 May. Then touring until 16 June

results.webTitle: Australia faces looming nuclear skills challenge to support Aukus submarines

fields.headline: Australia faces looming nuclear skills challenge to support Aukus submarines
fields.standfirst:
Pact with US and UK poses challenge to educate, train and recruit necessary personnel, experts say

  • Get our morning and afternoon news emails, free app or daily news podcast
fields.trailText: Pact with US and UK poses challenge to educate, train and recruit necessary personnel, experts say
fields.body:
Australia will need to significantly scale up local nuclear education and training to build sufficient expertise for the multi-decade Aukus submarine plan, experts say.

The Australian prime minister, Anthony Albanese, is expected to unveil the plan on Tuesday morning AEDT, with the UK prime minister, Rishi Sunak, and the US president, Joe Biden.

The Australian government estimates that Aukus will support 20,000 jobs over 30 years, across the Australian Defence Force, the public service and private industry.

Related: Aukus: 10 things we need to know about Australiaâ€™s nuclear submarine program

It poses a looming challenge to educate, train and recruit the necessary personnel, but experts say Australia has a good base from which to expand its nuclear industry.

Dr Patrick Burr, a senior lecturer in nuclear engineering at the University of New South Wales, said â€œwe definitely have a healthy nuclear industry in Australia, but itâ€™s often overlookedâ€?, citing nuclear safeguards and research into nuclear materials, nuclear medicine and waste. â€œOn the other hand â€¦ it needs to grow manyfold.â€?

Prof Gregory Lane, who convenes the master of nuclear science program at the Australian National University, agrees. â€œThereâ€™s a lot of knowledge about nuclear science. Itâ€™s required in all sorts of different areas: mining, health, sterilisation of materials for general industry, industrial gauging.â€?

  • Sign up for Guardian Australiaâ€™s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup

UNSW administers the only nuclear engineering degrees in the country, while the ANU is the only one to educate students in nuclear science.

â€œThe skills are available in Australia but there are specifics of [Aukus] that weâ€™ve never had to deal with and theyâ€™re going to have to be developed over time,â€? Lane said, adding: â€œFundamentally, we donâ€™t have a nuclear power program in Australia.â€?

The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (Ansto), a government agency, runs a nuclear research reactor at Lucas Heights in Sydney.

Lane describes the Ansto reactor as â€œone of the most technologically advanced reactors of its typeâ€?, which produces neutrons for experiments and to make medical isotopes. â€œBut thatâ€™s a very different beast to a reactor that is used for power and then a reactor that youâ€™re going put under water and needs to be absolutely failsafe.â€?

Burr and Lane agree that some nuclear personnel will need to be trained overseas. V Adm Jonathan Mead confirmed last week that some Royal Australian Navy officers were completing a nuclear reactor course in the US and also enrolled in UNSW and ANU programs.

Burr said UNSW had about 125 graduates each year across its undergraduate and postgraduate degrees, while Lane said more than 20 students were currently enrolled in the ANU masterâ€™s program.

For the nuclear-powered submarines, â€œsuitably qualified and experienced personnelâ€? will be required at three tiers of expertise, Burr said.

The first tier are those who are â€œnuclear awareâ€?, which would require only several months of training, Burr said. â€œIn a nuclear submarine â€¦ even something as simple as welding a pipe needs to be done by a nuclear-aware welderâ€? â€“ someone with additional training about the implications of working with nuclear-grade materials. â€œIf the weld goes wrong while youâ€™re at sea, it could be catastrophic.â€?

The second tier are people who â€œhave somewhere between five and 10 years of experience, and they typically have an education in engineering as wellâ€?.

The third tier, requiring the most expertise, are those with 20 to 30 yearsâ€™ experience and a PhD at a minimum.

UNSW modelling, led by Dr Edward Obbard, forecasts that operating and maintaining eight nuclear-propelled submarines would directly require several thousand tier 1 personnel, about 2,500 people at tier 2 and about 200 tier 3 subject matter experts.

Experts say scaling up local nuclear capabilities will require national coordination.

â€œThis needs to be a coordinated, collaborative effort from all nuclear training and education institutions in Australia,â€? Burr said. â€œAnsto will have a crucial role to play, not in education, but in some level of training and some level of government advisory.â€?

Lane said: â€œWe need to be looking at regulation, law, engineering, strategic studies, health â€“ all of these things matter in supporting a nuclear submarine effort.â€?

Ansto declined to comment.

fields.headline: Wisconsin senate supermajority win gives Republicans impeachment power
fields.standfirst: Republicans control 22 of 33 senate seats, giving them necessary votes to impeach officials including Democratic governor
fields.trailText: Republicans control 22 of 33 senate seats, giving them necessary votes to impeach officials including Democratic governor
fields.body:
Wisconsin Republicans won a supermajority in the state senate on Tuesday, giving them the necessary votes to impeach statewide officials, including the stateâ€™s Democratic governor and potentially state supreme court justices.

Wisconsin Republicans now control 22 of the senateâ€™s 33 seats after Dan Knodl, a Republican, narrowly defeated Democrat Jodi Habush Sinykin in a special election to represent a district that includes Milwaukeeâ€™s northern suburbs. Republicans also control 64 of the state assemblyâ€™s 99 districts. The Wisconsin constitution authorizes the state assembly to impeach â€œall civil officers of this state for corrupt conduct in office, or for crimes and misdemeanorâ€? by a majority vote. A two-thirds majority is required in the senate for a conviction.

Related: Liberal judgeâ€™s Wisconsin supreme court race win shows a shake-up in US politics

Republicans got their supermajority on the same night Janet Protasiewicz won a seat on the state supreme court, giving liberals a majority on the bench when she is seated in August. The new liberal majority could strike down the stateâ€™s legislative districts, which were drawn by Republicans and give them a virtually impenetrable majority in the legislature. The court is also expected to strike down the stateâ€™s 1849 abortion ban.

It is not clear whether state lawmakers will move forward with impeachment. The assembly has only once before impeached an official â€“ a judge in 1853 who was acquitted, according to the Associated Press. Itâ€™s also not clear who qualifies for impeachment, as the constitution does not define who is a â€œcivil officerâ€?.

Knodl, the Republican candidate who won on Tuesday, has said the legislatureâ€™s impeachment power would â€œcertainly be testedâ€? if he were elected. He has said he would consider impeaching Protasiewicz, who is currently a circuit court judge in Milwaukee, if she remained on the bench there. He did not say whether he would consider impeaching Protasiewicz as a supreme court justice, according to the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.

Duey Stroebel, a Republican state senator, told the New York Times that impeaching Protasiewicz over rulings on abortion and electoral maps was not likely â€œbut certainly not impossibleâ€?.

â€œIf she truly acts in terms of ignoring our laws and applying her own personal beliefs, then maybe thatâ€™s something people will talk about,â€? he told the Times. â€œIf the rulings are contrary to what our state laws and constitution say, I think there could be an issue.â€?

â€œWe canâ€™t say what the legislature will do or how likely any action is. But for this gerrymandered legislature to take steps toward removing democratically elected officials would be a profound abuse of power,â€? said Dan Lenz, a lawyer for Law Forward, a progressive non-profit legal group.

Barry Burden, director of the Elections Research Center at the University of Wisconsin â€“ Madison, told the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel that he thinks the legislature is ready to â€œplay hardballâ€?.

â€œRepublicans, in their majority for the last 12 years, have not been shy about exploring what tools are available to them and trying to push them as far as possible,â€? he said.

Republicans in Pennsylvania and Ohio in recent years have toyed with the idea of impeaching judges over their rulings on gerrymandering. Talk in both states quickly fizzled.

One of the jurists threatened with impeachment, former Ohio Republican supreme court justice Maureen Oâ€™Connor, said she never really took impeachment talk seriously.

Oâ€™Connor was one of the jurists threatened with impeachment after voting with Democrats to strike down GOP-friendly gerrymandered maps. â€œIt wasnâ€™t going to go anywhere â€“ political drama,â€? she said earlier this year.

fields.headline: â€˜Chasing unicornsâ€™: NSW Liberal minister rejects federal opposition push for nuclear power
fields.standfirst:
Matt Keanâ€™s comments come after Peter Dutton indicated support for nuclear energy could be part of future Coalition policy

  • Follow our Australia news live blog for the latest updates
  • Get our free news app; get our morning email briefing
fields.trailText: Matt Keanâ€™s comments come after Peter Dutton indicated support for nuclear energy could be part of future Coalition policy
fields.body:
The New South Wales energy minister and treasurer, Matt Kean, has accused the federal Coalition of â€œchasing unicornsâ€? over its push to overturn the moratorium on nuclear power in Australia.

Since it lost power at last monthâ€™s election, the new federal opposition has begun a push for the longstanding ban on nuclear power to be lifted.

Despite doing little to advance it as an energy source during its time in government, new Nationals leader, David Littleproud, has called for a â€œmatureâ€? conversation about the role of nuclear power in Australia.

Related: Thousands of public servants strike across New South Wales

The new leader of the opposition, Peter Dutton, has indicated that support for nuclear energy could be a part of the Coalitionâ€™s future policy platform, while former Nationals leader Barnaby Joyce has backed calls to overturn the moratorium.

â€œI donâ€™t think we should rule things out simply because itâ€™s unfashionable to talk about them,â€? Dutton said on Monday.

But amid a reduction in new nuclear projects globally, Kean poured cold water on the push by his Coalition colleagues in Canberra on Wednesday, saying pursuing nuclear energy generation in Australia was currently a â€œfantasyâ€?.

While conceding nuclear â€œmay have a role to play in our energy system in the futureâ€?, Kean said he hoped for a role for emerging nuclear technologies â€“ such as small modular reactors â€“ but that they would not help address rising energy costs in the short to medium term.

Kean referred to the UK governmentâ€™s underwriting of the construction of the Hinkley Point C station to the tune of about $300 a megawatt-hour, which he said was â€œthree times more expensive than the current electricity bills at the height that weâ€™re paying right nowâ€?.

He said the cost and timeline of new nuclear energy meant it was not realistic to consider it as an option.

  • Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

â€œNot only that, they started the build of [Hinkley Point C station] in around 2008,â€? he said. â€œItâ€™s now 2022 and it still hasnâ€™t been turned on, so we canâ€™t wait 20 years to chase some fantasy, which is large-scale nuclear.

â€œWhat we need to do is focus on things that are going to lower household bills today and set us up for more prosperity in the future.â€?

In 2019 the former federal Coalition government held a parliamentary inquiry into the role of nuclear. Chaired by the new shadow climate change and energy minister, Ted Oâ€™Brien, it recommended the government consider small modular reactors, which produce less energy but, proponents say, would be easier to keep safe.

Related: The Coalition didnâ€™t do much on nuclear energy while in office. Why are they talking about it now?

But many small nuclear reactor proposals overseas have been beset by problems , and Kean said that two of the firms pushing the use of the technology â€“ Rolls-Royce and US firm NuScale â€“ wouldnâ€™t have prototypes ready for construction until the next decade.

â€œSo people talking about nuclear as an asset to our energy challenges right now are literally chasing unicorns,â€? Kean said.

â€œThis is a fantasy, which is not ready at the moment. But who knows, at some time in the future, we may crack the code of small nuclear reactors and that could play a role in our energy mix.

â€œBut right now, we are focusing on the things that we know work [and] that we know are going to drive down household bills and thatâ€™s why weâ€™ve got our energy roadmap here in NSW to roll out solar, wind [and] pumped hydro storage with transmission lines. Because we know that thatâ€™s the best way to lower household bills to keep the lights on and to deliver clean, reliable electricity.â€?

fields.standfirst: â€˜Youâ€™re the frontlines of our collective defense,â€™ Biden tells Bucharest Nine group of eastern European countries on last day of trip
fields.trailText: â€˜Youâ€™re the frontlines of our collective defense,â€™ Biden tells Bucharest Nine group of eastern European countries on last day of trip
fields.body:
Joe Biden on Wednesday night condemned as a â€œbig mistakeâ€? Russian president Vladimir Putinâ€™s decision to suspend his countryâ€™s participation in the last remaining US-Russia nuclear arms control treaty.

Related: Putin aiming to divide US public opinion with nuclear treaty pullout, experts say

The comment came as the US president closed out his wartime visit to Europe, working to shore up partnerships with allies on Natoâ€™s perilous eastern flank â€“ even as Putin was drawing closer to China for help as his invasion of Ukraine neared the year mark.

Bidenâ€™s meeting with leaders of the Bucharest Nine nations in Warsaw came at the conclusion of a whirlwind, four-day visit to Ukraine and Poland meant to reassure allies that US support in fending off Russia is not at risk of waning.

In dramatic counterpoint, Putin on Wednesday played host in Moscow to Wang Yi, the Chinese Communist partyâ€™s most senior foreign policy official, as US intelligence warned that Beijing is considering supplying arms and ammunition to the worn-down Russian military.

The flexing of alliances was a fresh indication that both sides are digging in for prolonged conflict in Ukraine with the fighting expected to intensify with the arrival of spring.

Biden had delivered a ringing speech on western unity in Warsaw, a day after he swept into Kyiv unannounced for a visit with Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskiy. As Biden spoke in Poland, Putin announced that Russia was suspending its participation in the last remaining US-Russia nuclear arms control treaty.

Biden has now called that departure â€œa big mistakeâ€?. The exit is expected to have an immediate impact on US awareness of Russian nuclear activities. However, the pact â€“ known as New Start â€“ was already on life support following Moscowâ€™s cancellation late last year of talks that had been intended to salvage an agreement that each side has accused the other of violating.

â€œYouâ€™re the frontlines of our collective defense,â€? Biden told the Bucharest Nine, which comprises Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania and Slovakia. â€œAnd you know, better than anyone, whatâ€™s at stake in this conflict. Not just for Ukraine, but for the freedom of democracies throughout Europe and around the world,â€? he added.

These countries have worried that Putin could move to take military action against them next if heâ€™s successful in Ukraine. Biden responded to that anxiety by pledging that Natoâ€™s mutual defense pact is â€œsacredâ€? and that â€œwe will defend literally every inch of Natoâ€?.

Nato secretary general Jens Stoltenberg, who attended the meeting, pointed to past Russian conduct in Georgia and Ukraine and said: â€œWe cannot allow Russia to continue to chip away at European security. We must break the cycle of Russian aggression.â€?

fields.headline: Russia-Ukraine war at a glance: what we know on day 325 of the invasion
fields.standfirst:
UN nuclear watchdog boosting presence in Ukraine; hundreds of civilians trapped in eastern town of Soledar

  • See all our Russia-Ukraine war coverage
fields.trailText: UN nuclear watchdog boosting presence in Ukraine; hundreds of civilians trapped in eastern town of Soledar
fields.body:
• The United Nationsâ€™ nuclear watchdog announced it would boost its presence in Ukraine to help prevent a nuclear accident during the conflict. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) said it would soon have a permanent presence at all five of Ukraineâ€™s nuclear facilities. Currently, only the Russian-controlled Zaporizhzhia plant, which is near the frontline, has a permanent IAEA presence.

  • Ukraine has denied Russiaâ€™s claim that Putinâ€™s forces have captured Soledar. On Friday, Russiaâ€™s defence ministry said its forces had taken full control of the salt mining town. Ukrainian officials denied the Russian claim, suggesting they were still holding on and counterattacking, with the Ukrainian military spokesperson Serhii Cherevatyi reporting â€œongoing battlesâ€?.

  • Soledar is â€˜Verdun for 21st centuryâ€™ according to a top Ukraine official. Andriy Yermak, head of the office of the president of Ukraine, likened the fight for the town to the longest and bloodiest battle in the first world war.

  • Ukraineâ€™s president, Volodymyr Zelenskiy, said on Thursday that Ukrainian forces defending Bakhmut and Soledar in the east would be armed with everything they need to keep Russian troops at bay in some of the bloodiest fighting of the war.

  • Hundreds of civilians remain trapped in Soledar, Ukraine has said. Pavlo Kyrylenko, the governor of Donetsk, told Ukrainian state TV that 559 civilians remained in Soledar, including 15 children, and could not be evacuated.

  • Satellite images taken by Maxar Technologies show the destruction inflicted upon Soledar. The Guardian has a series of striking images from inside the eastern Ukrainian town.

  • Ukraine is confident Britain will announce it plans to send about 10 Challenger 2 tanks to Kyiv shortly, a move it hopes will help Germany finally allow its Leopard 2s to be re-exported to the embattled country. A formal announcement is anticipated on Monday but Ukrainian sources indicated they understood that Britain had already decided in favour.

  • Germany will continue to â€œweigh every step carefullyâ€? and consult with its allies on further weapons deliveries to Ukraine, chancellor Olaf Scholz has said. The German leader is facing mounting pressure to approve German-made battle tanks for Kyiv. Scholz said Berlin would keep its â€œleading positionâ€? as one of Kyivâ€™s top supporters but said he had no intention of being rushed on â€œsuch serious things that have to do with peace and war, with the security of our country and of Europeâ€?.

fields.standfirst:
Russian forces launched almost 400 strikes on Sunday, Zelenskiy says; UN nuclear watchdog to assess Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant

  • See all our Ukraine coverage
fields.trailText: Russian forces launched almost 400 strikes on Sunday, Zelenskiy says; UN nuclear watchdog to assess Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant
fields.byline: Samantha Lock, Tom Ambrose and LÃ©onie Chao-Fong
fields.body:
• Ukraine is to evacuate civilians from recently liberated areas of the Kherson and Mykolaiv regions. Residents of the two southern regions have been advised to move to safer areas in the central and western parts of the country, amid fears that the damage to infrastructure caused by the war is too severe for people to endure the winter.

  • Russian forces launched almost 400 strikes on Sunday in Ukraineâ€™s east as part of a campaign of artillery fire, Volodymyr Zelenskiy said in a Sunday night address. â€œThe fiercest battles, as before, are in the Donetsk region. Although there were fewer attacks today due to worsening weather, the amount of Russian shelling unfortunately remains extremely high,â€? the Ukraine president said. â€œIn the Luhansk region, we are slowly moving forward while fighting. As of now, there have been almost 400 artillery attacks in the east since the start of the day.â€? Russia has moved troops to reinforce positions in the eastern Donetsk and Luhansk regions after withdrawing from Kherson.

  • The southern Ukrainian city of Nikopol was hit by Russian shelling overnight, according to city officials. The shelling reportedly hit a residential area injuring a 78-year-old man, the Kyiv Independent reports the city governor, Valentyn Reznichenko, as saying.

  • The UN nuclear watchdog will conduct an assessment of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant on Monday after the site was shelled more than a dozen times over the weekend. The blasts damaged buildings and equipment, though none had been â€œcriticalâ€? for nuclear safety and security, the International Atomic Energy Agency said. Its head, Rafael Grossi, said the forces behind the shelling were â€œplaying with fireâ€?, adding that â€œit must stop immediatelyâ€?.

  • The Kremlin said it was concerned by what it claimed was repeated Ukrainian shelling of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant. It called on global powers to ensure that Kyiv ceased attacks on Europeâ€™s largest nuclear power station.

  • Russia also said that it would bring to justice those responsible for the alleged execution of Russian prisoners of war in Ukraine and that it would do everything possible to draw attention to what it has claimed is a war crime. Russia has accused Ukrainian soldiers of executing more than 10 Russian prisoners of war, citing a video circulating on Russian social media.

  • Ukraine denies the claims, arguing its soldiers were defending themselves against Russians who feigned surrender. The Ukrainian parliamentâ€™s commissioner for human rights responded on Sunday to videos circulated on Russian social media this week purporting to show the bodies of Russian soldiers killed after surrendering to Ukrainian troops. The Ukrainian ombudsman Dmytro Lubinets said â€œexcerptsâ€? of a video showed that Russians â€œusing a staged capture ... committed a war crime by opening fire on the Ukrainian armed forcesâ€?. This means the soldiers â€œcannot be considered prisoners of warâ€?, he said. A UN spokesperson told AFP it was â€œaware of the videosâ€? and was â€œlooking into themâ€?.

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that Ukraineâ€™s health system is â€œfacing its darkest days in the war so farâ€?. WHO regional director for Europe, Dr Hans Henri P Kluge, called for a â€œhumanitarian health corridorâ€? to be created to all areas of Ukraine newly recaptured by Kyiv, as well as those occupied by Russian forces.

  • Germany has offered Poland the Patriot missile defence system to help it to secure its airspace after a stray missile crashed in the country last week, the defence minister, Christine Lambrecht, said. â€œWe have offered Poland support in securing airspace â€“ with our Eurofighters and with Patriot air defence systems,â€? Lambrecht told the Rheinische Post and General Anzeiger. Ground-based air defence systems such as Raytheonâ€™s Patriot are built to intercept incoming missiles.

  • Negotiating with Russia would be â€œcapitulationâ€?, a key adviser to the Ukrainian presidency has said. Mykhaylo Podolyak said attempts by the west to urge Ukraine to negotiate with Moscow were â€œbizarreâ€? given a series of major military victories by Kyiv. He added it would mean that a country â€œthat recovers its territories must capitulate to the country that is losingâ€?. fields.headline: Aukus: nuclear submarines deal will cost Australia up to $368bn
fields.standfirst:
â€˜Rotational forcesâ€™ of US and UK nuclear-powered submarines set to visit Australia from 2027 as part of landmark pact

  • Follow our Australia news live blog for the latest updates
  • Get our morning and afternoon news emails, free app or daily news podcast
fields.trailText: â€˜Rotational forcesâ€™ of US and UK nuclear-powered submarines set to visit Australia from 2027 as part of landmark pact
fields.body:
Australia is to embark on one of its most significant, expensive and geopolitically consequential military tasks in a century: the push to acquire, operate â€“ and eventually build â€“ nuclear-powered submarines.

The program is forecast to cost $268bn to $368bn between now and the mid 2050s, most of it beyond the first four-year budget period, and will depend on help from the US and the UK.

As part of the multidecade nuclear-powered submarine plan unveiled on Tuesday, Australian taxpayers will pour â€œsubstantialâ€? funds into expanding American shipbuilding capacity, understood to be about $3bn in the first four years.

Australiaâ€™s prime minister, Anthony Albanese, said Aukus plan marked â€œa new chapterâ€? in the relationship between the three countries, as he joined the US president, Joe Biden, and the UK prime minister, Rishi Sunak, for the announcement in San Diego.

â€œThe Aukus agreement we confirm here in San Diego represents the biggest single investment in Australiaâ€™s defence capability in our history,â€? Albanese said.

Without directly naming China as a source of concern, Albanese said the plan reflected a shared determination to ensure all countries could â€œact in their sovereign interests free from coercionâ€?.

He said his government was â€œalso determined to promote security by investing in our relationships across our regionâ€?.

In a bid to reassure partners across the Indo-Pacific, Biden said it was important to note the Australian submarines would be nuclear-powered, not nuclear-armed.

â€œI want to be clear from the outset â€“ right off the bat â€“ so thereâ€™s no confusion or misunderstanding on this critical point,â€? Biden said. â€œAustralia is a proud non-nuclear weapons state, and itâ€™s committed to stay that way.â€?

Australia would invite â€œrotational forcesâ€? of US and UK submarines to visit the country from 2027.

The first Australian-built nuclear-powered submarines, fitted with vertical launch systems to fire cruise missiles, are due to enter into service in the early 2040s.

Related: Aukus: 10 things we need to know about Australiaâ€™s nuclear submarine program

The British-designed submarine â€œwill incorporate US technology such as propulsion plant systems and components, a common vertical launch system and weaponsâ€?, an Australian government fact sheet said. â€œThe Aukus partners will also develop a joint combat system as an expansion of the US-Australia combat system.â€?

The plan begins with increased visits by US submarines to Australian ports this year.

  • Sign up for Guardian Australiaâ€™s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup

From 2027 at the earliest, the UK and the US plan to establish a rotational presence of one UK Astute class submarine and up to four US Virginia class submarines at HMAS Stirling near Perth, Western Australia.

This will be called â€œSubmarine Rotational Force-Westâ€? (SRF-West). The Australian government argues this rotational presence â€œwill comply fully with Australiaâ€™s longstanding position of no foreign bases on its territoryâ€? because these submarines will be rotated through the location and will not be permanently based in Australia.

The three countries argue the rotational presence will â€œput our nations shoulder to shoulder as Australia builds the necessary operational capabilities and skills to steward and operate its own fleet of nuclear-powered submarinesâ€?.

The US and UK submarines would operate as sovereign assets under the command of, respectively, American and British commanders, but there would be â€œa significant degree of coordination in their activitiesâ€?, a senior Biden administration official said.

Beginning in the early 2030s, the US intends to sell Australia three Virginia class submarines, with the potential to sell up to two more if needed, pending approval from the US Congress.

The three governments argue this is â€œcritical to continue growing Australiaâ€™s ability to own and operateâ€? a fleet of nuclear-powered submarines and to ensure Australia does not experience any capability gap when its Collins class diesel-electric submarines are retired from the 2030s. The Australian government still plans to extend the life of some of these six conventional submarines, but the Aukus plans means it may not be necessary to carry out expensive upgrades on all of them.

The third phase of the program involves the design and construction of a submarine to be known as the â€œSSN Aukusâ€?, to be based on a UK design but incorporate US technology â€“ as the Guardian foreshadowed last week.

â€œAustraliaâ€™s long-term submarine will be a state-of-the-art platform that uses the best of US, UK and Australian technologies,â€? the official said.

â€œSSN Aukus will be built and deployed by both Australia and the UK. The United Kingdom intends to deliver its first SSN Aukus domestically in the late 2030s. Australia intends to deliver the first SSN Aukus built in Australia to the Royal Australian Navy in the early 2040s.

â€œThis is going to require significant improvements in industrial bases in all three countries.â€?

Senior Biden administration officials said the budget commitment from Australia towards the US industrial base was â€œanother manifestation of just how serious and critical this effort isâ€?. The $3bn would help the US reduce work backlogs on its own Virginia class submarines, and expand its production ability.

The funding for US domestic production could be a point of tension in Australia at a time when the budget is facing pressure on multiple fronts.

Related: Aukus will bolster stability in the Asia-Pacific, not undermine it | John Blaxland

The projected cost includes includes $9bn over the initial four-year budget period, or an increase of $3bn compared with the $6bn earmarked for the abandoned French project. Defence is being asked to offset that $3bn, which could come through changes to other defence projects.

Australian officials believe it is hard to estimate the cost over the life of the program, but have predicted a range based on all costs including acquisition and sustainment.

The long-term cost of the submarine plan is likely to be about 0.15% of Australiaâ€™s gross domestic product per year on average, compared with Laborâ€™s pre-election overall pledge to spend at least 2% of GDP on defence annually.

The Coalitionâ€™s defence spokesperson, Andrew Hastie, earlier offered bipartisan support to the overall Aukus deal, saying it is â€œtruly a multigenerational nation-building task for the Australian peopleâ€? and that it â€œcannot failâ€?.

Hastie also acknowledged the Aukus project would require some â€œhard choicesâ€? in the budget because â€œmoney doesnâ€™t grow on treesâ€?.
