results.webTitle: US scientists confirm â€˜major breakthroughâ€™ in nuclear fusion

fields.headline: US scientists confirm â€˜major breakthroughâ€™ in nuclear fusion
fields.standfirst: Successful experiment could pave way for abundant clean energy in future, but major hurdles remain
fields.trailText: Successful experiment could pave way for abundant clean energy in future, but major hurdles remain
fields.body:
Scientists have confirmed a major breakthrough has been made that could pave the way for abundant clean energy in the future after more than half a century of research into nuclear fusion.

Researchers at the US National Ignition Facility in California said fusion experiments had released more energy than was pumped in by the labâ€™s enormous, high-powered lasers, a landmark achievement known as ignition or energy gain.

The technology is far from ready to turn into viable power plants â€“ and is not about to solve the climate crisis â€“ but scientists hailed the breakthrough as evidence that the power of the stars can be harnessed on Earth.

Dr Arati Prabhakar, the policy director at the White House Office of Science and Technology, said: â€œLast week â€¦ they shot a bunch of lasers at a pellet of fuel and more energy was released from that fusion ignition than the energy of the lasers going in. This is such a tremendous example of what perseverance really can achieve.â€?

Fusion energy raises the prospect of plentiful clean power: the reactions release no greenhouse gases nor radioactive waste by-products. A single kilogram of fusion fuel, which is made up of heavy forms of hydrogen called deuterium and tritium, provides as much energy as 10m kilograms of fossil fuel. But it has taken 70 years to reach this point.

Speaking at the announcement on Tuesday, Jill Hruby, of the National Nuclear Security Administration (NNSA), said the US had â€œtaken the first tentative step towards a clean energy source that could revolutionise the worldâ€?.

The National Ignition Facility is a vast complex at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, near San Jose. It was built to perform experiments that recreate, briefly and in miniature, the processes unleashed inside nuclear bombs, enabling the US to maintain its nuclear warheads without the need for nuclear tests.

But the experiments are also stepping stones towards clean fusion power. To achieve the reactions, researchers fire up to 192 giant lasers into a centimetre-long gold cylinder called a hohlraum. The intense energy heats the container to more than 3m degrees celcius â€“ hotter than the surface of the sun â€“ and bathes a peppercorn-sized fuel pellet inside in X-rays.

The X-rays strip the surface off the pellet and trigger a rocket-like implosion, driving temperatures and pressures to extremes only seen inside stars, giant planets and nuclear detonations. The implosion reaches speeds of 400km per second and causes the deuterium and tritium to fuse.

Each fusing pair of hydrogen nuclei produces a lighter helium nucleus, and a burst of energy according to Einsteinâ€™s equation E=mc2. Deuterium is easily extracted from seawater, while tritium can be made from lithium which is found in the Earthâ€™s crust.

In the latest experiment, researchers pumped in 2.05 megajoules of laser energy and got about 3.15MJ out â€“ a roughly 50% gain and a sign that fusion reactions in the pellet were driving further fusion reactions. â€œThe energy production took less time than it takes light to travel one inch,â€? said Dr Marvin Adams, at the NNSA.

Immense hurdles remain, however, in the quest for fusion power plants. While the pellet released more energy than the lasers put in, the calculation does not include the 300 or so megajoules needed to power up the lasers in the first place. The NIF lasers fire about once a day, but a power plant would need to heat targets 10 times per second. Then there is the cost of the targets. The ones used in the US experiment cost tens of thousands of dollars, but for a viable power plant, they would need to cost pence. Another issue is how to get the energy out as heat.

Dr Kim Budil, the director of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, said with enough investment, a â€œfew decades of research could put us in a position to build a power plantâ€?. A power plant based on alternative technology used at the Joint European Torus (JET) in Oxfordshire could be ready sooner, she added.

â€œIn some senses everything changes; in another, nothing changes,â€? said Justin Wark, a professor of physics at the University of Oxford and the director of the Oxford Centre for High Energy Density Science. â€œThis result proves what most physicists always believed â€“ fusion in the laboratory is possible. However, the obstacles to be overcome to make anything like a commercial reactor are huge, and must not be underestimated.â€?

He said that asking how long it could take to overcome the challenges was like asking the Wright brothers how long it would take to build a plane to cross the Atlantic just after their maiden flight. â€œI understand that everyone wants to think of this as being the great solution to the energy crisis. It is not, and whoever says it is with any certainty is misleading.

â€œIt is highly unlikely that fusion will impact on a timescale sufficiently short to impact our current climate change crisis, so there must be no let up on our efforts in that regard.

â€œThe latest results also show that the basic science works â€“ the laws of physics do not prevent us from achieving the goal â€“ the problems are technical and economic. As Niels Bohr, the Nobel prize-winning atomic physicist once said: â€˜Prediction is very difficult, especially when it is about the future.â€™â€?

Dr Mark Wenman, a reader in nuclear materials at Imperial College London, called the achievement a â€œfantastic scientific breakthrough â€“ something we have not achieved in 70 years of tryingâ€?. But he said: â€œChallenges remain of how you can get the energy out of the system, how you can sustain the energy for long enough to be useful, how you scale up that energy and whether the energy can be cheap enough to compete with other sources.â€?

results.webTitle: Crises on multiple fronts threaten Benjamin Netanyahuâ€™s grip on power

fields.headline: Crises on multiple fronts threaten Benjamin Netanyahuâ€™s grip on power
fields.standfirst: Support for prime minister wanes as his â€˜plot to overturn Israelâ€™s democracyâ€™ is seen as threat to national security
fields.trailText: Support for prime minister wanes as his â€˜plot to overturn Israelâ€™s democracyâ€™ is seen as threat to national security
fields.body:
On Friday afternoon, Israelâ€™s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, found himself standing at the side of a remote road in the vast desert valley that runs the length of the occupied West Bankâ€™s frontier with Jordan.

Along with his defence minister, Yoav Galant, Netanyahu was inspecting the scene of a shooting attack earlier in the day that killed British-Israeli sisters Maia and Rina Dee, 20 and 15, and left their 45-year-old mother Lucy fighting for her life. An Israel Defence Forces (IDF) search for the perpetrator is still under way.

â€œFor this challenge as well, we are standing united, unified, sure of our righteousness,â€? Netanyahu said in comments broadcast by Israeli television. â€œWe will act together with total backing for our forces.â€?

Unfortunately for the prime minister, his remarks rang hollow for many Israelis. This week Israel has faced flare-ups in violence on almost every front â€“ East Jerusalem, the West Bank, the Gaza Strip, Lebanon and Syria.

The security establishment has also been unnerved by the sudden rapprochement between Saudi Arabia â€“ the regionâ€™s geopolitical heavyweight, with whom Israel is seeking warmer ties â€“ and the countryâ€™s arch enemy, Iran.

As if the intersecting border crises were not enough to deal with, Israel is also undergoing unprecedented upheaval at home sparked by the governmentâ€™s bitterly contested plan to overhaul the judiciary.

Related: Netanyahu is leading a coup against his own country. But the threat is not only to Israel | Jonathan Freedland

Dozens of former senior defence, security and intelligence officials have opposed the proposals weakening the supreme court on the grounds they are anti-democratic. Israelâ€™s crucial military reservists, including almost all of those serving in its most important air force unit, have joined the nationwide protests and said they will refuse to attend for service, setting alarm bells ringing over the reliability of the chain of command and operational capacity.

Galant might have been standing by his side as the pair pledged to find the Dee sistersâ€™ killer, but two weeks ago, Netanyahu fired him after he became the first senior government official to voice objections to the judicial changes.

Public pressure quickly forced the prime minister to back down, and announce that legislation weakening the supreme court would be postponed until after the Knessetâ€™s Passover recess. But the lingering uncertainty over Galantâ€™s position and the appointment of the inflammatory national security minister, Itamar Ben-Gvir, does not exactly convey strength and stability â€“ particularly now.

Leaked Pentagon documents that surfaced on Saturday suggesting the Mossad, Israelâ€™s spy agency, encouraged its staff and the Israeli public to participate in the protest movement, have added to a growing perception among Israelâ€™s many foes that such internal discord represents an opportunity.

â€œI served in the army for decades, and I did not see behaviour as reckless as that of Netanyahu now,â€? Moshe Yaâ€™alon, a former defence minister and IDF chief of staff, said in an address at a protest in Tel Aviv on Saturday night.

â€œHis obsessive plot to overturn Israelâ€™s democracy represents an immediate threat to Israelâ€™s security â€¦ Our enemies are watching, and our deterrence is waning.â€?

Despite corruption scandals and a colourful private life, during his previous five stints as prime minister Netanyahu was generally seen as a safe pair of hands when it came to Israelâ€™s security.

Now, even among the rightwing public that voted in the current coalition of extremist and ultra-religious parties, dwindling support suggests that image is fading, and the Israeli leader could once again be forced out of office. A total of 69% of voters gave the government a bad grade on its first 100 days in office, according to polling released by Israelâ€™s Channel 12 on Sunday.

Hebrew media reported over the weekend that government sources had suggested they would be forced to launch a major military operation in the coming weeks, after the conclusion of the sensitive overlapping Passover and Ramadan holiday period, in order to bolster the coalitionâ€™s legitimacy in the eyes of the public.

Israelâ€™s current government was elected on a platform promising order and security. So far, they have delivered the exact opposite.

results.webTitle: Power to the people: the neighbours turning their London street into a solar power station

fields.headline: Power to the people: the neighbours turning their London street into a solar power station
fields.standfirst: Lynmouth Road, Walthamstow, is about to become its own power station, with solar energy for 30 homes. Now the artists responsible want us all to change how we heat our homes
fields.trailText: Lynmouth Road, Walthamstow is about to become its own power station, with solar energy for 30 homes. Now the artists responsible want us all to change how we heat our homes. By Anna Fielding
fields.body:
Lynmouth Road appears unremarkable. It consists largely of redbrick Victorian terraces. There are similar streets throughout the area, in Walthamstow, northeast London. Some houses are pebble-dashed. Some have doors painted in contemporary grey. There are wind chimes, geraniums in boxes, wheelie bins and the occasional cat sitting on a gate post. The only unusual feature is the number of windows displaying an A4 poster with the words â€œPower Stationâ€? printed in the font used by polling stations.

Power, in the sense of the energy, is at the forefront of everyoneâ€™s mind. Energy bills have reached record highs and are still rising, with the war in Ukraine highlighting how fragile energy supplies can be. This yearâ€™s Cop27 climate conference promised money to poorer countries to assist with damage caused by climate change, yet no agreement was reached on phasing out fossil fuels. The idea of cleaner power, generated closer to home, should feel like an obvious goal. But, at the moment, there are no large-scale programmes dedicated to making it happen. Instead, there are people like Dan Edelstyn and Hilary Powell.

Well, if someone came and said there was a way of helping with the bills, youâ€™d be over the moon, wouldnâ€™t you?

Ejaz Hussain

These two are on the roof of their house, sitting on a bed they have just assembled. It is made up with a knitted blanket, bright sheets and a cheap foam mattress that is plastic-wrapped against the elements. Facing one way you can see their narrow back garden that ends when it hits the railway embankment. Turn around and you look down into their street, Lynmouth Road, which Dan and Hilary want to turn into a solar power station. They are living on their roof as a crowdfunder for the project. â€œI think it will be fine,â€? says Hilary, who has been scanning both the sky and the weather forecast. â€œI only get scared when the children say they want to come up, then I turn to jelly.â€?

The couple are artists and filmmakers. They live in the middle of the street, with their children, EsmÃ©, 12, and George, 10, and the familyâ€™s two dogs. â€œIt is a street that has a sense of community,â€? says Hilary, down from the roof and sitting at their kitchen table. â€œThat became apparent with the Covid mutual aid group that was set up.â€? And it was during lockdown that a sentence from economist Ann Pettiforâ€™s book, The Case for the Green New Deal, which makes a strong argument for total decarbonisation and a financial system based on fairness, struck both of them. The phrase was: â€œEvery building a power station.â€? â€œWe clung on to that,â€? says Hilary.

There was also Peopleâ€™s Power by American writer Ashley Dawson. â€œHe wrote about energy democracy and tackling the power monopolies within the energy industry,â€? she adds.

The idea started to take shape. Could they make a home into a power station? And not just their home, but perhaps their whole street by linking the houses together into a grid? Buying and installing a solar system for an average three-bedroom house costs around Â£10,000, they discovered. Linking them together would be hard â€“ the technology is complex, especially in an urban area with lots of individual buildings. They did more research. And then they started talking to neighbours.

â€œWell, if someone came and said there was a way of helping with the bills, youâ€™d be over the moon, wouldnâ€™t you?â€? says Ejaz Hussain, 71, now retired. â€œIf it comes off, Iâ€™ll know that Iâ€™ve been blessed.â€?

Sipke Visser, 45, is a photographer and retoucher. He lives with his wife, their two children and his father-in-law. â€œI know Dan and Hilary, so I wasnâ€™t that surprised,â€? he says, â€œBut I do think if a complete stranger were to knock on my door, I would be very sceptical.â€?

â€œWe looked at putting solar panels up quite a few years ago and we found the cost of doing it was too much,â€? says Pippa Evans, 57, who works at an adoption and fostering therapeutic agency. â€œSo I was intrigued when this flyer came through the letterbox. I wanted to know how it was going to work and if we could afford it. Were Dan and Hilary going to coordinate everything? I knew about their previous project. So I knew they were quite good at making things happen.â€?

The previous project was Bank Job. In 2018, the couple started working in an empty building, a former bank on one of Walthamstowâ€™s main streets. They printed artwork that looked like bank notes, complete with pictures of people from local community projects, and sold them, raising Â£40,000 in the process. Half the money went back to the local groups. And with the remaining Â£20,000 they bought up Â£1.2m worth of high-interest debt owed by people in the local community. â€œYou can buy it for so much less because the assumption is that it wonâ€™t be paid off,â€? says Dan. They let the debtors know there was nothing left to pay, although GDPR rules meant this could only be done by sending letters via a debt broker. Then they packed up the paper records into a gold-coloured van and blew the whole thing up on wasteland outside Canary Wharf, the towers of the UKâ€™s financial sector looming in the background. The documentary they made about the project came out in 2021 and the remains of the van are currently on display at the Fitzwilliam Museum in Cambridge.

They describe Power Station as a natural evolution. â€œItâ€™s also a show-and-do project,â€? says Dan. â€œWeâ€™re learning as we go and weâ€™re sharing it as we learn it.â€?

â€œWeâ€™re not setting ourselves up as experts,â€? adds Hilary. â€œThere isnâ€™t just one solution and we donâ€™t know everything about kilowatts per hour, so weâ€™re a conduit. Weâ€™re learning and educating ourselves and others and then also building partnerships with people who are experts.â€? Their own expertise, they say, is in making a project come to life and then drawing attention to the issues using art and storytelling.

As of 2019 there were around 300 community energy projects in the UK covering 67,000 homes, according to the thinktank Green Alliance. The sector was hit when the governmentâ€™s community energy strategy was scrapped, with at least 66 projects folding in 2017 and more becoming precarious. The initial grand design for Lynmouth Road was for an entire street interlinked, powered for free and managed by a cooperative. But the mixture of rented and private, leasehold and freehold, and various mortgages with various banks meant dropping uniform infrastructure across the rooftops would be almost impossible. â€œIt turns out that not many people fully own their roof,â€? says Dan.

While the whole street canâ€™t be linked now, Dan harbours a dream of making this happen as the project grows and would love to see a community battery so that those who canâ€™t have solar panels could also access power. And with 30 households involved â€“ nearly half the residencies in Lynmouth Road â€“ there is enough for the street to become a solar energy hotspot and model for what other streets could also achieve in terms of renewable power.

The project, as it stands, will be funded in various ways. There are grants from organisations, such as the London Community Energy Fund. Thereâ€™s the crowdfunder, running while Dan and Hilary sleep on top of their house. They have also printed a new run of bank notes to sell, the notes and large handprinting machines currently occupying half of their living room. Buying solar equipment in bulk brings the price down, so participating residents can offer to pay, but the scheme is free for those who need it to be. Each resident will be given a grant for their solar installation and deal with the company directly.

As we sit on the bed on the roof, the surveyor from the solar company is finishing his assessments. He climbs the scaffolding at the back of the house to come and chat, although he doesnâ€™t make it all the way up. â€œItâ€™s a bit ironic, in my line of work, but Iâ€™m not great with heights,â€? he says.

Not everyone in the street has wanted or been able to take part. â€œSome people just shut the door before we started speaking,â€? says Dan. â€œThen there were people who were dying or divorcing or moving. Or having a loft conversion.â€? Loft conversions came up a lot. They can make rooftops unsuitable for solar panels, but the more frequent issue was that of imminent building work.

Andy Richford, 70, is one of the people planning a loft conversion. An editorial consultant working in scientific publishing and with a background in ecology, he believes the project will amplify a necessary message. â€œIâ€™ve been banging on about it for years,â€? he says. â€œI might not be able to participate in terms of getting the panels, but making a difference is important to me. Putting solar panels on top of houses, with a direct feed into the house, means energy isnâ€™t lost in transmission and we donâ€™t have the worry of covering acres and acres of farmland or wild land.â€?

The ground on which Lynmouth Road stands was once part of the marshland on the banks of the River Lea. The remaining marsh is less than half a mile away, some of it a Site of Special Scientific Interest and all of it popular with picnickers, dog walkers, runners and the occasional raver. The Lynmouth Road area, says Hilary, who has been looking into its history, was a watercress farm until the houses started going up in 1886. The Victorian era was Walthamstowâ€™s first growth spurt. Boosted by new rail links, the land filled up with houses for workers. It remained a largely working-class area for most of the 20th century, but in the 2000s house prices accelerated andWalthamstow, with its garden terraces, good schools and decent transport links, became a prime location. Between 2012 and 2019, house prices more than doubled.

â€œIt used to be full of very long-term residents,â€? says Hilary. â€œOne family staying in a house for decades. We moved in around 14 years ago and found a newspaper from 1945.â€? Dan also mentions a former resident, Dorothy Burroughs, who spent her 100 years living on the street, only leaving to briefly enter a care home before her death last year. Dorothy remembered when electricity first came to the houses in the 1930s. â€œShe said that people needed to be shown what to do and how to use appliances. People would come round and demonstrate.â€?

Ejaz Hussain has lived here since 1978. He has worked all of his adult life, including 20 years at a local food processing factory, now demolished to make way for flats. â€œIâ€™m struggling, although the mortgage is paid. Iâ€™ve got two daughters, one at college, one about to go to university. We put them first. But the bills come in and the house needs repairs and Iâ€™m on my pension,â€? he says. Like many of his neighbours, he had also looked at solar panels, but had been unable to afford them. He has also watched the street change around him. â€œIn the early days it was brilliant, simple. You said good morning to your neighbours, they said good morning to you. Then it got that if you said hello, people would give you a funny look.â€? The Power Station project, he says, has meant the people in the street talk to one another once more. â€œThis is what we want, the community spirit,â€? he says. â€œIt costs nothing to look after one another.â€?

The collective nature of the scheme has been a draw for many of the residents. â€œWe all have concerns about the environment,â€? says Chris Humphreys, 49, who works in education and lives with his wife, Catherine, and their two sons. â€œAnd you try and do your little thing, but to be part of something bigger is very appealing. You see whatâ€™s happening in the news at the moment and you know it wonâ€™t be those people who make changes for the better. Itâ€™s got to start at the grassroots. Iâ€™ve never been especially active politically, but Iâ€™m very happy to stand alongside our neighbours in what I think is hopefully a practical and positive solution.â€?

â€œI want to be part of the solution, even if itâ€™s just a small part,â€? says Dee Tweedie, 48, who has been involved with the project from the beginning and went door-to-door with Dan and Hilary to explain the idea. â€œWe all want to save the planet and the prices of everything are rising in tandemâ€¦ energy, food, mortgage. But you donâ€™t always know what you can do when itâ€™s just you and your family. Itâ€™s been lovely to meet so many of our neighbours. Thereâ€™s camaraderie. Maybe thatâ€™s how it felt during the war.â€?

Itâ€™s building on the sense of community that started to grow during the pandemic

Pippa Evans

â€œItâ€™s building on the sense of community that started to grow during the pandemic,â€? says Pippa Evans. â€œTo me, itâ€™s almost as important as the energy. Itâ€™s within human nature to be self-centred at times and I think the political climate has encouraged that. But humans are sociable and weâ€™re interdependent and those aspects can be emphasised when weâ€™re working together and helping create something. As a community, we can make bigger changes than as individual people.â€?

â€œThe energy for what we do is drawn from anger, but I donâ€™t think you would necessarily see that as a tone in our films or in our work,â€? says Dan. â€œBut you wouldnâ€™t see us here, doing all this, if we didnâ€™t feel an intense sense of how absurd our political and social realities are. Weâ€™d like to see a kinder world, but weâ€™ve created a system that profits a very narrow minority and so many more people could be living more meaningful and useful lives.â€?

â€œI can be really angry,â€? says Hilary. â€œWe live in a society where Matt Hancock can be on celebrity TV and you think, â€˜What the fuck is going on? This is sick, itâ€™s like The Hunger Games. And we acquiesce. And the corruption and vandalism of those in charge are just forgotten. At the same time, we canâ€™t be paralysed,â€? she continues. â€œI hope this can wake others up and make them realise you can take action, and that the worst thing would be to sit in despair and do nothing.â€?

The Power Station may not be actively producing energy just yet, but it has generated an idea that is already flowing to the rest of the area. Dan and Hilary are working with five local primary schools, including the one their son attends, to arrange funding and installation via the Solar for Schools project. People in neighbouring streets have started asking how they could join in.

â€œWeâ€™re busy behind the scenes, working out how it could become a street-by-street model,â€? says Hilary. â€œI hope, after the first wave, when there are people sharing testimonials, others will want to be involved, too.â€? On their wall they have an aerial photograph of the road, with the houses already involved marked by coloured Post-It notes.

â€œI was kind of heartbroken when the obstacles to doing the whole street started to pile up,â€? says Dan. â€œBut I started to realise it doesnâ€™t really matter. We have 30 households, and more and more people expressing interest. Three nearby streets are starting to organise themselves. And we can share what weâ€™ve learned. You need someone to coordinate, otherwise scheduling the surveys is tough. You need at least 20 people. But you can go from there.â€?

The surveys on Lynmouth Road are just wrapping up. If all goes to plan, the panels will start to go up in January. â€œI feel like weâ€™ve promised people something and I want everyone to see itâ€™s really happening,â€? says Hilary. But even without the solar panels, the street has started to change. â€œWhen society is organised from the top down, you feel reliant on the government to change things,â€? says Pippa Evans. â€œBut if you have brave individuals who stand up and gather other people around themâ€¦ We can stand up for ourselves, we can do things ourselves.â€?

â€œWe can be powerful, us, the people who should be powerless,â€? says Dan. He is on his rooftop with the street â€“ and the geraniums and cats and wheelie bins â€“ spread out two storeys below. â€œWe do have the power to change things.â€?

For all information on the Power Station, go to power.film. To contribute to the project, visit crowdfunder.co.uk/p/power-station. For free access to the membership scheme and to learn how to do it A, B, C style, go to membership.power.film

fields.headline: How safe are Ukraineâ€™s nuclear power plants amid Russian attacks?
fields.standfirst:
Experts assess the risks after fire burned for several hours at Zaporizhzhia nuclear facility

  • Russia-Ukraine war: live news
fields.trailText: Experts assess the risks after fire burned for several hours at Zaporizhzhia nuclear facility
fields.body:
The attack of Ukraineâ€™s Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant â€“ Europeâ€™s largest â€“ has triggered international concern about the safety of the countryâ€™s facilities.

Ukraine is heavily dependent on nuclear energy â€“ it has four main power plants, with 15 reactors, generating about half its electricity. On Friday, the president, Volodymyr Zelenskiy, said artillery fire at the plant could have caused destruction equal to â€œsix Chernobylsâ€?.

For now, say experts, the immediate danger from the attack appears to be low, with Russia having as much to lose as anyone.

â€œIf thereâ€™s going to be a major nuclear incident itâ€™s because something deliberately is being done,â€? said Tom Scott, professor in materials at the University of Bristol. â€œSurely nobody is going to be that stupid. It doesnâ€™t benefit anyone. The wind is blowing towards Russia at the moment.â€?

Related: Ukraineâ€™s Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant seized by Russians after shelling, say authorities

Rafael Mariano Grossi, head of the IAEA UN nuclear watchdog, confirmed on Friday that radiation levels at the site had remained normal, that all safety systems at the plant were unaffected and that the reactors themselves had not been breached. The projectile had hit an administrative building some distance away within the site.

Of the six reactors at the site, five are in safety mode, with one unit operating at 60% capacity. Reports from the site suggest that staff have continued to control operations.

While Zelenskiy was quick to highlight the potential for a Chernobyl-scale incident, the technology at Zaporizhzhia is quite different. The Chernobyl reactor used graphite to keep the nuclear reaction under control and the disaster was caused by a graphite fire. The Zaporizhzhia plant â€“ and those at Ukraineâ€™s other main plants, Khmelnitski, Rovno and South Ukraine â€“ has pressurised water reactors, a more modern type that do not involve graphite. So a fire such as the one at Chernobyl will not occur.

Pressurised water reactors have a steel vessel at their centre, like a giant pressure cooker with 20cm-thick walls. This contains the nuclear fuel and radioactive products from the nuclear reaction and is designed to withstand damage from events such as earthquakes and aeroplane crashes, although not specifically artillery shells. The inner vessel is surrounded by a heavily steel reinforced concrete containment building â€“ Chernobyl did not have this.

For a Chernobyl-level event, both the pressure vessel and concrete bioshield would need to be breached and this would probably require intentional targeting with huge explosives.

Nevertheless, there is deep concern that any attack aimed at taking control of a facility could still lead to a nuclear incident. Experts are especially alarmed that an internationally recognised principle â€“ ensuring the physical integrity of civil nuclear plants â€“ has been disregarded.

â€œItâ€™s very clear that this is against the Geneva conventions,â€? said Scott. â€œIt is a flagrant breach of international laws and agreements to do this.â€?

Grossi, who says the situation â€œcontinues to be extremely tense and challengingâ€?, said on Friday that he had offered to travel to the Chernobyl site to facilitate a negotiation between Ukraine and Russia, with the aim of agreeing a framework to guarantee the safety of nuclear plants during the conflict.

A concerning worst-case scenario, Scott said, was damage to the cooling capability at Zaporizhzhia or one of Ukraineâ€™s other facilities.

Even after reactors are switched off, they need continual cooling for several weeks in order to remove residual heat from the core. The cooling systems rely on diesel generators, so any damage to these â€“ or if fuel was siphoned off for other purposes â€“ could cause an incident similar to that at Fukushima, where the plantâ€™s power failed after a tsunami. That could result in the reactors overheating and residual water turning into steam, which could melt the fuel inside the reactor and cause the release of radiation into the atmosphere.

There is also a concern about spent fuel storage facilities being disturbed. After fuel is taken out of a reactor core, it is put into spent pool ponds for a year or more to physically cool down before being transferred to long-term, more secure storage.

results.webTitle: Julius Caesar review â€“ timeless account of the flimsiness of power

fields.headline: Julius Caesar review â€“ timeless account of the flimsiness of power
fields.standfirst:
Royal Shakespeare theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon
Atri Banerjeeâ€™s RSC production stresses the remarkable universality of the playâ€™s examination of leaders and the led
fields.trailText: Atri Banerjeeâ€™s RSC production stresses the remarkable universality of the playâ€™s examination of leaders and the led
fields.body:
Early in the Trump administration, there was controversy over a New York staging of Julius Caesar in which the actor playing the slain tyrant resembled the 45th president. British prime ministers change so rapidly these days that a similar approach would risk recasting during rehearsal. However, Atri Banerjeeâ€™s deliberately non-Spitting Image RSC production stresses the remarkable universality of the playâ€™s dissection of leaders and the led, fulfilling Cassiusâ€™s prophecy that Caesarâ€™s murder will be â€œacted over in states unborn and accents yet unknownâ€?.

The wider political context now is the flimsiness of power. Of the core world leaders who attended the 2019 G7 meeting, only two remain in power and one, Japanâ€™s Shinzo Abe, was assassinated after leaving office. As the psephological sage John Curtice has pointed out, almost no head of government who led a country through Covid is still in post. Such churn gives urgency to the scene in which the conspirators discuss wanting power and what they will do with it; Brutus, leaving Mark Anthony in play, pays later for his kindness/weakness.

In this version, Brutus and Cassius are played by Thalissa Teixeira and Kelly Gough, the charactersâ€™ pronouns changed to â€œsheâ€? and â€œherâ€?, although curiously Anthonyâ€™s eulogy for Brutus still predicts that people will say: â€œThis was a man!â€? Thereâ€™s an intriguing hint of an anti-feminist dystopia in which women â€“ also including Ella Dacresâ€™ Octavius Caesar â€“ are forced, like some nuns, to take male names, and this may also be an attempt at complete gender-fluidity of language, but the switches sometimes jar between eye and ear.

Movement director Jennifer Jackson introduces a prologue and interludes in which actors swirl and howl, reminiscent of Bill Violaâ€™s video installations of choreographed mobs. This underlines the playâ€™s reflections on crowds and power, and more is made than usual of the feast of Lupercal being as significant a date as the Ides of March, this play sometimes seeming to be previewing Macbethâ€™s supernatural framing. Startlingly, stabbed Caesar bleeds black blood, possibly hinting at the oil greed of capitalism, which stains his assassins for the rest of the play.

The crackle of these additions is sometimes absent from the dialogue. Though Banerjee eschews the enclosing Perspex box so modish in classical productions, there can feel to be a cold screen between actors and audience, possibly because the staging must fit nine different theatres on a UK tour.

Related: â€˜Iâ€™m no white man in a togaâ€™: Thalissa Teixeira on having a stab at Brutus

As Mark Antony, William Robinson suggests a weak, wonkish figure who rises higher than rivals expect, underlining Shakespeareâ€™s prescience in identifying all known political types, as do Teixeira and Goughâ€™s respective embodiments of an intellectual but unworldly and impatiently passionate legislator: most systems have such a Brutus and Cassius. Nigel Barrettâ€™s cockily populist Caesar rings various alarm bells around the world, and Matthew Bulgo makes Casca the sort of cultured, honey-voiced thug that all administrations seem to have. Annabel Baldwin strikingly extends the role of Soothsayer into scene-shifter and conscience of the populace.

That Julius Caesar ends with an unlikely and uneasy coalition in charge will also prove, in many places, further evidence of the eternal political truths of the play.

  • At the Royal Shakespeare theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon, until 8 April. Then touring 20 April-24 June

results.webTitle: Nuclear is not the answer to the UKâ€™s energy requirements | Letter

fields.headline: Nuclear is not the answer to the UKâ€™s energy requirements
fields.standfirst: We need more honesty about the problems of the proposed Sizewell C plant, writes Rae Street
fields.trailText: Letter: We need more honesty about the problems of the proposed Sizewell C plant, writes Rae Street
fields.body:
In his letter (22 December), Tom Smith describes the problems of storing the radioactive waste that is being produced by the UK nuclear reactors, and says that we need more honesty about these issues. The latter is also true of other problems with â€œnew nuclear buildâ€?. Take, for example, the proposed Sizewell C reactor on the east coast.

The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has estimated that extreme â€œsea level eventsâ€? could occur â€œat least once per year at many locations by 2050â€?. Sizewell C will be built near the sea on marshland. One engineer has estimated that the land where the reactor would be built will turn into a promontory encircled by the sea. Clearly the reactor site could be flooded.

Then there is the problem of obtaining uranium, which is currently the fuel for the nuclear reactors. The UK has to import uranium from across the world. It is mainly mined on the land of Indigenous people â€“ in the US, in Canada, in Australia and in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The miners and their families have suffered years of ill health and even death from proximity to uranium. At the same time, having to import uranium means that this is not an independent source of energy for the UK.

The government and the opposition have completely ignored all warnings; they go doggedly on, supporting the construction of the new nuclear reactor at Sizewell and considering plans to build others. But nuclear is not the answer to the UKâ€™s energy requirements. Apart from anything else, it is vastly expensive. The money it swallows should be put into developing genuine sustainable energy: tidal, wind and solar.
Rae Street
Littleborough, Greater Manchester

results.webTitle: US accuses Russia of violating key nuclear arms control treaty

fields.headline: US accuses Russia of violating key nuclear arms control treaty
fields.standfirst: Washington condemns Moscow for what it says is a â€˜refusal to facilitate inspection activitiesâ€™ regarding New Start treaty
fields.trailText: Washington condemns Moscow for what it says is a â€˜refusal to facilitate inspection activitiesâ€™ regarding New Start treaty
fields.body:
The United States has accused Russia of violating the New Start treaty, the last major pillar of post-cold war nuclear arms control between the two countries, saying Moscow was refusing to allow inspection activities on its territory.

The treaty came into force in 2011 and was extended in 2021 for five more years. It caps the number of strategic nuclear warheads that the United States and Russia can deploy, and the deployment of land- and submarine-based missiles and bombers to deliver them.

The two countries, which during the cold war were constrained by a tangle of arms control agreements, still account together for about 90% of the worldâ€™s nuclear warheads.

Washington has been keen to preserve the treaty but ties with Moscow are the worst in decades over Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, an element that could complicate attempts by Joe Bidenâ€™s administration to maintain and reach a follow-on agreement.

â€œRussiaâ€™s refusal to facilitate inspection activities prevents the United States from exercising important rights under the treaty and threatens the viability of US-Russian nuclear arms control,â€? a state department spokesperson said in emailed comments.

Related: Russia suspends US inspections of its nuclear weapons arsenal

Moscow in August suspended cooperation with inspections under the treaty, blaming travel restrictions imposed by Washington and its allies after Russian forces invaded neighbor Ukraine in February last year, but said it was still committed to complying with the provisions of the treaty.

The state department spokesperson added that Russia had a â€œclear pathâ€? for returning to compliance by allowing inspection activities, and that Washington remains ready to work with Russia to fully implement the treaty.

â€œThe New Start treaty remains in the national security interests of the United States,â€? the spokesperson said.

Talks between Moscow and Washington on resuming inspections under New Start were due to take place in November in Egypt, but Russia postponed them, accusing the United States of â€œtoxicity and animosityâ€?, and neither side has set a new date.

On Monday, Russia told the United States that the treaty could expire in 2026 without a replacement because it said Washington was trying to inflict â€œstrategic defeatâ€? on Moscow in Ukraine.

Asked if Moscow could envisage there being no nuclear arms control treaty after 2026, deputy foreign minister Sergei Ryabkov told the RIA state new agency: â€œThis is quite a possible scenario.â€?

The United States has supplied more than $27bn in security assistance to Ukraine since the invasion, including more than 1,600 Stinger anti-aircraft rocket systems, 8,500 Javelin anti-tank missile systems and 1m 155mm artillery rounds.

Related: Are Putinâ€™s nuclear threats really likely to lead to Armageddon?

Russian president Vladimir Putin has issued thinly veiled threats to use nuclear weapons in Ukraine, reviving cold war era fears of an apocalyptic war.

Shortly after taking office, Biden extended New Start by five years until 2026, giving time to negotiate while preserving what the Democratic administration sees as an important existing treaty.

The previous administration of Donald Trump had ripped up previous arms control agreements and had been hesitant to preserve New Start in its current form, saying that any nuclear treaty must also include China, whose arsenal is rapidly growing but still significantly below those of Russia and the United States.

results.webTitle: Climate activists must target power structures, not the public | Letters

fields.headline: Climate activists must target power structures, not the public
fields.standfirst: Dr Laura Thomas-Walters, Tim Williamson and Paul Chandler respond to Jack Shenkerâ€™s article that asked if the disruptive tactics of groups such as Extinction Rebellion and Just Stop Oil are working
fields.trailText: Letters: Dr Laura Thomas-Walters, Tim Williamson and Paul Chandler respond to Jack Shenkerâ€™s article which asked if the disruptive tactics of groups such as Extinction Rebellion and Just Stop Oil are working
fields.body:
I am an environmental social scientist and climate activist. As Jack Shenker describes in his article (The existential question for climate activists: have disruption tactics stopped working?, 6 March), Extinction Rebellionâ€™s recent decision to stop disrupting the public caused quite a fuss. Some people applauded the move as they thought it would favourably shift public opinion, while others insisted public disruption needs to remain a primary tactic to garner wider attention.

Unfortunately, both camps are missing the point â€“ once you have enough dedicated activists, the public is largely irrelevant to achieving political change. It is not the opinion, or even attention, of the public that matters, it is whether or not you are disrupting structures of power. Historical social movements have shown this repeatedly.

Despite what we may like to believe in a democracy, public opinion is only one small influence on the government. It may theoretically give governments a mandate to act, but real change must first overcome powerful opposition from the structures that support governments, such as business and the legal and financial systems. The role of activists is to change the cost-benefit equation for these structures until it is more beneficial for them to accept change than to carry on with the status quo.

For climate activists, the real question is not about the efficacy of disruptive tactics, it needs to be about targets. And the answer is power, not the public.
Dr Laura Thomas-Walters
Llandaff, Cardiff

â€¢ What can we do about the climate crisis? What form should our protest take? Do the actions of Extinction Rebellion risk alienating those who they look to for support? Indigo Rumbelow, a supporter of Just Stop Oil and co-founder of Insulate Britain, takes the view that the debate â€œis not between those who want to take â€˜moderateâ€™ or â€˜radicalâ€™ action. Itâ€™s between those who are standing by doing nothing at all, and those who are doing something. Thatâ€™s where the line is drawn.â€?

But it should never be like this. A democracy should allow voters to choose how their country is governed. There should be a constitutional requirement for those of us seriously concerned about the climate crisis to have our views expressed in government. This obviously doesnâ€™t happen. Our government consists only of Tory MPs representing a minority of voters. Yes, we have offshore wind generation, but otherwise their response is desperately inadequate.

As a result, we have to resort to any kind of protest we feel might make a difference. If our civilisation truly wants a route to survival, we need a representative democracy with proportional voting.
Tim Williamson
Bath

â€¢ Jack Shenker asks if disruption tactics have stopped working in climate protests. I would ask: did they ever work? Starting with the suffragists and suffragettes (or possibly earlier), most radical and progressive movements have had extreme wings, driven by a sense of frustration that their voice is not being listened to.

I would love to see some academic work try to quantify the effect of publicity-seeking â€œstuntsâ€? against patient political foot-slogging. Having spent most of my life doing the latter, I feel politics does work. I was born into a world where homosexuality and abortion were illegal and mixedâ€‘race marriage regarded as immoral. That has changed. Conventional politicians such as Roy Jenkins and David Steel did their stuff â€“ and succeeded.
Paul Chandler
Brighton

results.webTitle: Nuclear nightmare: reckless leaders push the world back to the brink | Simon Tisdall

fields.headline: Nuclear nightmare: reckless leaders are pushing the world back to the brink
fields.standfirst: Itâ€™s not just Putin or the refusal of the major powers to disarm. Unstable regimes in Israel and North Korea are also raising global nuclear tensions
fields.trailText: Itâ€™s not just Putin or the refusal of the main powers to disarm. Irresponsible regimes in Israel and North Korea are also raising global nuclear tensions
fields.body:
Leaders of unstable nuclear-armed states do dangerous and foolish things when under stress. They miscalculate, provoke, overreach. Given the febrile state of bilateral relations, last weekâ€™s aerial military clash between Russia and the US over the Black Sea inevitably intensified fears of nuclear escalation. The incident dramatised how dangerous Vladimir Putin, cornered by his existential Ukraine blunder, truly is â€“ and the risks he is increasingly prepared to run. But heâ€™s not the only one.

As often the case over the past year, Putin relied on American restraint. US forces could easily have gone after the offending Su-27 fighter at its Crimea base. Each time Russiaâ€™s president darkly hints at going nuclear, that once unthinkable prospect becomes a little less outlandish â€“ and western leaders must steel their nerves. Russiaâ€™s repeated bombing of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant fits this pattern of minacious brinkmanship.

Russia possesses about 1,600 deployed strategic nuclear warheads, out of a military stockpile of about 4,500. Like the US and other nuclear weapons states, it is modernising and adding new systems. At the same time, a vital safety net of arms control treaties dating from the Soviet era is shredding. Last month, Putin ditched New Start, which caps deployed strategic nuclear arsenals. It was Russiaâ€™s last such treaty with the US.

In other words, at the very moment when the Kremlin is under unprecedented pressure and US-Russia relations are at their most tense since the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, the political channels, agreed mechanisms and binding limits that could help avoid a nuclear collision are less robust and dependable than ever before. While the risk of unintended nuclear confrontation is ever-present, Putinâ€™s recklessness makes it infinitely worse.

Israel is another nuclear-armed state under extreme stress, mostly due to its volatile rightwing prime minister. Benjamin Netanyahuâ€™s perceived attempt to avoid jail by destroying judicial independence, and with it Israelâ€™s democracy, has caused uproar. Significantly, his â€œcoupâ€? is under fire from serving members of the military and former defence ministers as well as much of civil society.

If this destabilising nationwide upheaval were taking place in Pakistan, for example, loud international expressions of concern about the security of its secretive nuclear arsenal would be heard. So the comparative silence over the safety and control of Israelâ€™s 90 or so undeclared warheads is disturbing. Amid an extraordinary standoff between Netanyahu and US president Joe Biden, Israelâ€™s president, Isaac Herzog, fears civil war. â€œThe abyss is within touching distance,â€? he said last week.

There is good reason to worry about what Netanyahu may do, Putin-like, to escape his self-made troubles. He has threatened to bomb Iranâ€™s nuclear facilities in the past. Israeli media suggest he may now be planning an attack. Netanyahu warned this month of a â€œhorrible nuclear warâ€? unless Tehranâ€™s uranium enrichment programme was halted. Would he start a Middle East conflict to save his skin? Past experience suggests he might.

If the US and its allies were not so distracted by Ukraine, they might pay more attention to Netanyahuâ€™s antics. Much the same may be said of the developing crisis in nuclear-armed North Korea, where inherent weakness is compounded by looming famine. New doubts surround dictator Kim Jong-unâ€™s health and a problematic succession. Stirring the pot, China and Russia back him against the west despite the danger he poses.

Kim spent last week firing off nuclear-capable ballistic missiles like thereâ€™s no tomorrow â€“ and there may not be if he carries on like this. Analysts anticipate another underground atomic test. Kim regularly threatens the US â€“ and South Korea and Japan, which met last week to ponder what to do. Earlier this month he ordered his military to prepare for â€œreal warâ€?. Is Kim waving or drowning, seeking attention or waxing desperate? Ignoring North Korea, which is unspoken western policy, stores up trouble.

Itâ€™s difficult to tell from his lugubrious appearance but Xi Jinping, Chinaâ€™s newly anointed president for life, is a leader under severe pressure, too. His zero-Covid policy damaged a struggling economy and sparked something close to popular revolt. His aggressive foreign policy, debt diplomacy and rights abuses have produced a global anti-China backlash. By vowing to conquer US-backed Taiwan come what may, Xi has created another rod for his back.

A Chinese invasion of Taiwan, which CIA director William Burns predicts may happen by 2027, is a probable nuclear flashpoint â€“ especially if it goes badly for Xi. Itâ€™s estimated China has about 400 operational nuclear warheads, rising to approximately 1,000 by 2030. American nuclear-armed ships, submarines and bombers constantly patrol the western Pacific.

For his part, Xi can point to continuing US and UK nuclear weapons modernisation, and to last weekâ€™s deal to provide Australia with nuclear-powered submarines. China complained at the UN that the deal breached the nuclear non-proliferation treaty by transferring fissile material and nuclear technology to a non-nuclear weapons state.

In an arrogant riposte, the US claimed it would actually strengthen non-proliferation efforts â€“ without explaining how. Iran and others will register this double standard.

The longstanding refusal of the main powers to disarm is the root cause of rising nuclear tensions â€“ but irresponsible present-day political leaders greatly exacerbate the danger. â€œThe United States and its allies â€¦ are faced with a choice,â€? wrote Lt Col Brent Stricker of the US Naval War College in a bleak assessment of the changing nuclear world order. They could either â€œrestart arms limitation discussions to include both Russia and China, or restart the arms raceâ€?.

The former course is wildly improbable at this juncture. So the old cold war-era nuclear helter-skelter ride towards mutually assured destruction looks set to resume and accelerate â€“ under new, stressed-out management. Assuming no one presses the button first.

results.webTitle: Spain renews call for US to remove soil from nuclear accident site

fields.headline: Spain renews call for US to remove soil from nuclear accident site
fields.standfirst: Contaminated earth in AlmerÃ­a is result of 1966 air crash involving a B-52 loaded with hydrogen bombs
fields.trailText: Contaminated earth in AlmerÃ­a is result of 1966 air crash involving a B-52 loaded with hydrogen bombs
fields.body:
Nearly 60 years after a midair collision dumped four US hydrogen bombs in south-eastern Spain, strewing radioactive plutonium across the landscape, Spanish officials have renewed efforts to have Washington cart off tens of thousands of cubic metres of contaminated soil to the US for storage.

A source at Spainâ€™s ministry of foreign affairs confirmed on Monday that it had formally requested the US takes action to remove the radioactive earth. The request is in line with a non-binding agreement struck between the two countries in 2015 and which included a US commitment to â€œarrange for disposal of the contaminated earth at an appropriate site in the United Statesâ€?.

As the US had yet to formally respond, the source declined to offer further details. El PaÃ­s, the Spanish newspaper that first reported the story, said the request had been lodged a few months ago. The US government did not respond to a request for comment.

The demand is the latest chapter in a saga that traces back to January 1966 when a US B-52 bomber loaded with nuclear weapons collided with a tanker plane during a midair refuelling operation off the coast of Almeria, Spain. Seven of the two planesâ€™ 11 crew members were killed.

Four hydrogen bombs tumbled from the B-52; one was later recovered intact in the Mediterranean while the other three crashed on land near the coastal village of Palomares.

While the bombs did not explode, two of the plutonium-filled detonators went off, scattering 7lb of radioactive plutonium-239 across the landscape.

The US sent about 1,600 servicemen to the crash site to recover the weapons and clean up the contamination. About 1,400 tonnes of contaminated soil was shipped to a facility in South Carolina.

Both countries were eager to downplay the collision, which took place during the height of the cold war and as Spain was in the grip of the Franco dictatorship.

Amid fears that the risk of radioactive contamination would harm the countryâ€™s budding tourism industry, Spainâ€™s then tourism minister and the US ambassador took a widely publicised swim in the sea off the coast of Palomares in the weeks after the incident.

Concerns over the lingering impacts of the collision catapulted back into the spotlight in 2007, after a study suggested up to 50,000 sq metres of land remained contaminated. The affected area was fenced off and barred from being used for agriculture or development.

In 2015 Madrid and Washington signed off on an agreement to negotiate a binding deal for the siteâ€™s remediation. â€œWe have to build on todayâ€™s signing to take further action to resolve â€“ once and for all â€“ this very important issue,â€? the then US secretary of state, John Kerry, said during a joint press conference with the Spanish foreign minister at the time, JosÃ© Manuel GarcÃ­a-Margallo.

Little was done to implement the agreement, however, as elections ushered in changes in Spain and the US. The Spanish governmentâ€™s recent decision to take up the issue again with the US was prompted by the assessment that bilateral relations were â€œat their best in years,â€? sources told El PaÃ­s, leaving Madrid hopeful that some progress could be made before Spain heads to the polls for general elections at the end of the year.

fields.standfirst: Eight people detained in Russia over Crimea bridge attack; Zaporizhzhia nuclear power station loses off-site power again
fields.trailText: Eight people detained in Russia over Crimea bridge attack; Zaporizhzhia nuclear power station loses off-site power again
fields.byline: Helen Sullivan, Martin Belam and LÃ©onie Chao-Fong
fields.body:
• At least seven people were killed and eight injured in a Russian strike on a crowded market in the town of Avdiivka, the governor of Ukraineâ€™s eastern Donetsk region reported. â€œThere is no military logic in such shelling - only an unbridled desire to kill as many of our people as possible and intimidate others,â€? Pavlo Kyrylenko said.

  • Vladimir Putin has said Russia is ready to resume gas supplies via one link of the Nord Stream 2 pipeline that remains operational. The ball was now in the EUâ€™s court on whether it wanted gas supplied via it, the Russian president said in his address to the Russian Energy Week international forum.

  • Eight people have been detained over the weekendâ€™s attack on the Crimea bridge, and Russiaâ€™s security forces have named a senior figure from Ukraine as being behind them. A statement from the Federal Security Service (FSB) claimed â€œthe organiser of the terrorist attack on the Crimean Bridge was the Main Intelligence Directorate of the Ukrainian Defence Ministry, its head Kyrylo Budanov, employees and agents. Currently, five citizens of Russia, three citizens of Ukraine and Armenia, who participated in the preparation of the crime, have been detained within the framework of the criminal case.â€?

  • A senior Ukrainian official dismissed the investigation as â€œnonsenseâ€?. â€œThe whole activity of the FSB and Investigative Committee is nonsense,â€? Ukraineâ€™s public broadcaster Suspilne cited interior minister spokesman Andriy Yusov as saying. He described the FSB and Investigative Committee as â€œfake structures that serve the Putin regime, so we will definitely not comment on their next statementsâ€?.

  • The head of the International Atomic Energy Agency has described developments at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant (ZNPP), which has lost off-site power again for a period of time, as â€œdeeply worryingâ€?. Energoatom, the Ukrainian state-owned company that manages the ZNPP accused Russian forces occupying it of refusing a convoy of company vehicles carrying diesel to refuel the plantâ€™s generators after shelling of a substation in the Dnipropetrovsk region caused the plant to lose power.

  • Ukraineâ€™s ministry of reintegration has confirmed that 37 Ukrainian children who were illegally deported to Russia have now returned home. The children had been deported from the Russian-occupied territory of Kharkiv region in August, it said in a statement on Facebook.

  • The European Commission wants at least â‚¬18bn (Â£15.8bn) in emergency aid to help Ukraineâ€™s government stay afloat next year, as an economic crisis looms in the country. Officials in Brussels think the EU should provide at least half the â‚¬3bn-â‚¬3.5bn monthly running costs it estimates the Ukrainian state needs to function in 2023, the Guardian has learned.

  • The Netherlands will deliver â‚¬15m worth of air defence missiles to Ukraine in reaction to Russian air raids on Ukraine earlier this week.

  • Pope Francis on Wednesday condemned Russiaâ€™s â€œrelentless bombingsâ€? of Ukrainian cities and appealed to â€œthose who have the fate of the war in their handsâ€? to stop. He was quoted as saying â€œMy heart is always turned to the people of Ukraine, especially those living in places hit by the bombingâ€?. The pontiff prayed for an intercession that â€œmay change the hearts of those who have the fate of the war in their hands, so that they may cease this wave of violence and rebuild peaceful coexistenceâ€?.

  • Russiaâ€™s president, Vladimir Putin, is a â€œrational actor who has miscalculated significantly,â€? US president Joe Biden said in a clip of a CNN interview broadcast late on Tuesday.

  • The Kremlinâ€™s spokesperson, Dmitry Peskov, said rhetoric from western leaders on the potential use of nuclear weapons was â€œprovocativeâ€?. Peskov added that there had been no attempt from either Washington or Moscow to discuss a potential meeting between Biden and President Vladimir Putin.

  • A crowdfunding appeal that was launched after Russian attacks on cities across the country on Monday has raised $9.6m (Â£8.7m) in 24 hours for the purchase of kamikaze drones for the Ukrainian armed forces. An initial 50 Ram II drones, unmanned aerial vehicles with a 3kg explosive payload, designed and built by Ukrainian companies, will be bought with the money, along with three control stations.

  • Russia continued to attack key infrastructure in Ukraine with missile strikes on Tuesday. Amid warnings from the UN and some Nato countries that Moscow may be committing a war crime with its continuing deadly blitz on civilian targets, Russiaâ€™s defence ministry confirmed its troops continued to launch long-range airstrikes on Ukraineâ€™s energy and military infrastructure.

  • The leaders of the G7 condemned Russiaâ€™s most recent missile attacks on cities across Ukraine â€œin the strongest possible termsâ€? and vowed to stand â€œfirmlyâ€? with Kyiv â€œfor as long as it takesâ€?.

  • Ukraineâ€™s president, Volodymyr Zelenskiy, asked G7 leaders to supply more air defence systems and for an international monitoring mission on the Belarusian border.

  • Roughly 30% of Ukraineâ€™s energy infrastructure has been hit by Russia since Monday, officials said. As millions in Ukraine are facing blackouts due to the attacks, the government has urged civilians to cut their electricity use and not use domestic appliances such as ovens and washing machines.

  • Russian strikes have damaged hundreds of cultural sites, Zelenskiy said as he urged the UN cultural agency to expel Russia, which currently holds the rotating presidency of the Unesco World Heritage Committee.

Amid deep divisions among senior Conservatives, the strategy will enrage environmentalists, who say the governmentâ€™s plans are in defiance of its own net-zero targets and neglect alternative measures that experts say would provide much quicker relief from high energy bills.

The prime minister will launch the plan on Thursday, after a period of intense political wrangling set against the backdrop of Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, which has convulsed energy markets and sent home energy bills rocketing.

Whitehall sources said rows over the strategy between No 10, the Treasury and the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) continued right up until the eve of publication, with an insider describing the process as â€œchaosâ€?.

The cabinet eventually agreed that atomic energy would form the backbone of the strategy, and up to eight new reactors are planned.

Targets for offshore wind and solar power generation will also be raised, in a push for 95% of Great Britainâ€™s electricity to come from domestic low-carbon energy sources by 2030.

But the plans risk infuriating environmental campaigners, after the opportunity to remove barriers to more onshore wind farms appeared to fall victim to Tory in-fighting, new North Sea drilling won the governmentâ€™s blessing, and ministers appeared to open the door to fracking.

Opposition parties were scathing about the strategy. Two former energy secretaries from Labour and the Liberal Democrats branded it â€œludicrousâ€? and â€œhopelessâ€? for failing to expand onshore wind power or tackle energy efficiency.

Ed Miliband, the Labour climate change secretary, said the energy relaunch was â€œin disarrayâ€? and would do nothing to help the millions of families facing an energy crisis now. â€œBoris Johnson has completely caved to his own backbenchers and now, ludicrously, his own energy strategy has failed on the sprint we needed on onshore wind and solar â€“ the cheapest, cleanest forms of homegrown power,â€? he said.

Ed Davey, the Lib Dem leader and another former energy secretary, added: â€œThe Conservativesâ€™ failure to help people cut their bills with an urgent energy insulation programme, the failure to back super-cheap onshore wind and the failure to back properly new technologies like tidal power and hydrogen is a total betrayal of families and pensioners across the UK.â€?

The energy strategy outlines a wide-ranging plan to boost domestic energy production through a range of power sources. They include:

  • Increasing nuclear capacity from 7 gigawatts to 24GW

  • Offshore wind target raised from 40GW to 50GW (from 11GW today)

  • Solar could grow five times from 14GW to 70GW by 2035

  • An â€œimpartialâ€? review into whether fracking is safe

  • Up to 10GW of hydrogen power by 2030

Johnson said the plan will â€œreduce our dependence on power sources exposed to volatile international prices we cannot control, so we can enjoy greater energy self-sufficiency with cheaper billsâ€?.

â€œThis plan comes in light of rising global energy prices, provoked by surging demand after the pandemic as well as Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine.

â€œThis will be central to weaning Britain off expensive fossil fuels, which are subject to volatile gas prices set by international markets we are unable to control, and boosting our diverse sources of homegrown energy for greater energy security in the long term.â€?

While some renewable domestic energy sources won backing, the wind industryâ€™s hopes of getting the green light to double onshore capacity to 30GW appeared to have fallen victim to opposition from within the Conservative party to new projects, particularly in England.

Communities who live near planned new projects could be offered incentives, such as guaranteed lower energy bills, but the plan does not include targets for increased generation.

Cabinet colleagues have been at odds over whether to reform planning laws to spur faster development of onshore windfarms, which can take as little as a year to build and start contributing to the grid, but were described by transport secretary Grant Shapps as an â€œeyesoreâ€? at the weekend.

Shapps and chief whip Chris Heaton-Harris, a longstanding opponent of onshore wind, are among a group of MPs who have sought to thwart a major rollout in England, with Michael Gove and business minister Kwasi Kwarteng â€“ whose brief includes energy â€“ among those to have pushed back.

The business department is also understood to have been thwarted by the Treasury in a plan to channel Â£300m of budget underspend into a rapid rollout of energy efficiency upgrades that could aid homeowners in bringing down their bills.

Solar won significant backing from the government, which said planning rules could be relaxed to favour development on non-protected land, enabling capacity to increase up to fivefold, from 14GW to 70GW. The target for hydrogen power will be doubled to 10GW by 2030 â€œsubject to affordability and value for moneyâ€?.

Overall, â€œcleanâ€? energy sources could provide up to 40,000 new jobs, reaching a total of 480,000 by 2030, the government will say.

But alongside the push for renewables sit plans that will alarm opponents of further oil and gas exploitation.

The British Geological Survey will conduct an â€œimpartialâ€? review of whether fracking for shale gas can proceed safely, a move likely to spark fury among environmental campaigners about the controversial technology, particularly after a moratorium was imposed on the process in 2019.

New North Sea oil and gas projects are also likely to be accelerated, although the strategy sets out proposals to limit emissions as much as possible.

Nuclear power forms the centrepiece of the energy strategy. Ministers expect to begin a competitive selection process as early as next year for a new round of nuclear projects, although tensions between Downing Street and the Treasury over the cost of new projects, which are expected to require government investment, have yet to be resolved.

The target of producing 25% of Britainâ€™s electricity from atomic energy is likely to require tens of billions of pounds of new investment from private companies, with the state providing guarantees under a new â€œregulated asset baseâ€? funding model.

A Â£120m â€œFuture Nuclear Enabling Fundâ€? will be launched this month in the hope of kickstarting projects, while a new body called Great British Nuclear will oversee the plans.

National Grid has predicted that peak electricity demand will hit 85GW by 2050, up from 60GW today, because of factors such as the electrification of vehicles and home heating.

The government said it could approve up to eight new reactors to help reach a target of generating 24GW of the total from nuclear power plants, which typically have more than one reactor.

Some of the increase can be achieved by extending the life of the Sizewell B reactor, while the Hinkley Point C project is due for completion in 2027 and Rolls-Royce has the governmentâ€™s blessing for small reactors nicknamed â€œmini-nukesâ€?.

Major projects that have already been through some form of planning, such as Sizewell C and Wylfa, on Anglesey, have been singled out by the government as among the first to win support.

The target also implies new plants at sites whose locations have already been approved but where no plans are under way, such as Oldbury in Gloucestershire or Moorside (Sellafield) in Cumbria.

While Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine has prompted global discussion on how to reduce reliance on Kremlin-controlled oil and gas, it appears to have cooled the governmentâ€™s resolve to limit the UKâ€™s own fossil fuel production.

Drilling for oil and gas in the North Sea is at odds with the governmentâ€™s own net-zero targets. The government will justify the plans by saying that local exploitation of hydrocarbons emits less carbon than importing supplies from elsewhere.

Ministers have also commissioned a new study to examine safety concerns about fracking, which polls have shown is deeply unpopular with the public.

That should have referred to offshore wind and domestic low-carbon energy sources.

fields.headline: Jeremy Hunt accused of â€˜Â£20bn gambleâ€™ on nuclear energy and carbon capture
fields.standfirst:
Campaigners say chancellor is in the grip of the fossil fuel and nuclear lobbies and is â€˜squandering taxpayersâ€™ moneyâ€™

â€¢ Hunt U-turns on planned cut to energy bills support

â€¢ What Huntâ€™s U-turn on energy bills support means for you
fields.trailText: Campaigners say chancellor is in the grip of the fossil fuel and nuclear lobbies and is â€˜squandering taxpayersâ€™ moneyâ€™
fields.body:
Jeremy Hunt has been accused of wagering a â€œdangerous gamble on unproven technologiesâ€? in an effort to decarbonise Britainâ€™s energy industry after ploughing more than Â£20bn into a series of projects.

In his budget speech, the chancellor confirmed plans to spend the money over the next two decades on carbon capture and low carbon energy projects; announced a competition to co-fund small nuclear plants and launched a consultation to classify nuclear as â€œenvironmentally sustainableâ€?.

The government has created Great British Nuclear, a body designed to ease the creation of nuclear projects which are regularly delayed and over budget, and set a target for nuclear to â€œprovide up to one quarter of our electricity by 2050â€?.

Hunt, who has been under pressure to respond to Joe Bidenâ€™s $369bn (Â£306bn) of climate subsidies, said: â€œIncreasing nuclear capacity is vital to meet our net zero obligations.â€?

However, climate campaigners attacked the drive, which had no giveaways for the solar or wind industries.

Ami McCarthy, Greenpeace UKâ€™s political campaigner, said: â€œThis misguided budget shows the stranglehold fossil fuel and nuclear lobbies have on this government. Why else would it take such a dangerous gamble on unproven technologies?

â€œSquandering taxpayersâ€™ money on nuclear reactors that donâ€™t even exist yet and fanciful carbon capture is irresponsible, and does nothing to reduce our emissions now.

â€œCommitting to Â£20bn over 20 years is frankly pathetic compared to the green growth investments being made in the US, EU and China.â€?

Helen Clarkson, chief executive of Climate Group, said: â€œThis spring budget overlooks cheap and clean renewable energy, and instead rebrands nuclear as â€˜environmentally sustainableâ€™ and throws cash at carbon capture technology. This was a missed opportunity to renew the UKâ€™s commitment to climate leadership.â€?

Senior nuclear industry figures said the reclassification would help attract investors to fund the proposed Sizewell C nuclear power plant in Suffolk, which the government has committed Â£700m towards.

Tom Greatrex, chief executive of the Nuclear Industry Association, called the move a â€œhuge step forward for UK energy security and net zeroâ€?.

But Stuart Murphy, founder of tidal energy specialist TPGen24, said: â€œThere is nothing environmentally sustainable about a finite resource which leaves a legacy of hazardous waste.â€?

Britainâ€™s energy industry has been under the spotlight since the war in Ukraine pushed already-high oil and gas prices higher.

On Wednesday, Hunt confirmed a widely expected U-turn in on a planned cut to energy support for households. He also said that from July, 4m households on prepayment meters will see their bills aligned with those on direct debits, who currently pay less.

The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) said it expected to see taxes brought in from oil and gas firms for 2022-23 quadruple on last year to Â£11bn, representing just a fifth of the Â£55bn in annual global profits of British energy giants BP and Shell.

The government introduced a windfall tax on North Sea oil and gas operators last May. The OBR said falling wholesale gas prices meant it had cut its forecasts by Â£4bn this year, and Â£10bn next year, compared with forecasts made in November.

The OBR also said it expects the bailout of Bulb to cost a further Â£3bn â€œbut much of that cost is ultimately likely to be recoupedâ€? over an uncertain timeframe following the sale of the bust energy supplier to Octopus Energy.
